events.title: The Fugitives Introduce Themselves and Their Troubles
detailed_summary: Huck provides a description of the two men he rescued.

One was elderly, around seventy or older, with a bald head and very gray whiskers. He wore an old, battered slouch hat, a greasy blue woolen shirt, ragged old blue jeans tucked into his boot-tops, and only one home-knit suspender. He also carried an old long-tailed blue jeans coat with brass buttons over his arm.
The other man was about thirty years old and dressed in a similarly shabby manner.
Both men carried large, dilapidated-looking carpet-bags.
After breakfast, as they all relaxed and talked, it became clear that the two fugitives did not know each other prior to their meeting on the path.
The older man inquired of the younger one about the cause of his trouble.

The younger man explained that he had been selling a tartar-removing product for teeth, which unfortunately also tended to remove tooth enamel. He had lingered in a town one night too long and was making his escape when he encountered the older man on the trail, who warned him of approaching pursuers and asked for help.
The younger man, expecting trouble himself, agreed to flee with the older one.

The older man then shared his own predicament: he had been conducting a successful temperance revival for about a week and was very popular, especially with the women, earning five or six dollars a night.
However, a rumor began circulating the previous night that he secretly indulged in alcohol from a private jug.

A Black person alerted him that morning that a mob was quietly gathering with dogs and horses, intending to give him a brief head start before hunting him down to tar and feather him and ride him on a rail. Consequently, he fled immediately, without waiting for breakfast.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One of these fellows was about seventy or upwards, and had a bald head and very gray whiskers.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I didn’t wait for no breakfast—I warn’t hungry.”

events.text_segment:
One of these fellows was about seventy or upwards, and had a bald head and very gray whiskers. He had an old battered-up slouch hat on, and a greasy blue woollen shirt, and ragged old blue jeans britches stuffed into his boot-tops, and home-knit galluses—no, he only had one. He had an old long-tailed blue jeans coat with slick brass buttons flung over his arm, and both of them had big, fat, ratty-looking carpet-bags.
The other fellow was about thirty, and dressed about as ornery. After breakfast we all laid off and talked, and the first thing that come out was that these chaps didn’t know one another.
“What got you into trouble?” says the baldhead to t’other chap.
“Well, I’d been selling an article to take the tartar off the teeth—and it does take it off, too, and generly the enamel along with it—but I stayed about one night longer than I ought to, and was just in the act of sliding out when I ran across you on the trail this side of town, and you told me they were coming, and begged me to help you to get off. So I told you I was expecting trouble myself, and would scatter out with you. That’s the whole yarn—what’s yourn?
“Well, I’d ben a-runnin’ a little temperance revival thar, ’bout a week, and was the pet of the women folks, big and little, for I was makin’ it mighty warm for the rummies, I tell you, and takin’ as much as five or six dollars a night—ten cents a head, children and niggers free—and business a-growin’ all the time, when somehow or another a little report got around last night that I had a way of puttin’ in my time with a private jug on the sly. A nigger rousted me out this mornin’, and told me the people was getherin’ on the quiet with their dogs and horses, and they’d be along pretty soon and give me ’bout half an hour’s start, and then run me down if they could; and if they got me they’d tar and feather me and ride me on a rail, sure. I didn’t wait for no breakfast—I warn’t hungry.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: One of these fellows was about seventy or upwards, and had a bald head and very gray whiskers. He had an old battered-up slouch hat on, and a greasy blue woolen shirt, and ragged old blue jeans britches stuffed into his boot-tops, and home-knit galluses—no, he only had one. He had an old long-tailed blue jeans coat with slick brass buttons flung over his arm, and both of them had big, fat, ratty-looking carpet-bags. The other fellow was about thirty, and dressed about as ornery. They had come bustling through the woods, looking scared and out of breath. When they saw me, they sung out, "Save us, boy! Are they after you?" I said, "No, nobody's after me. Are they after you?" "Well, you bet they are. If they catch us they'll lynch us, sure." "Goodness gracious! What did you do?" "Nothin' at all. We're temperance people—done nothing but good." They begged me to let them come aboard the raft, saying they were being chased by men and dogs. The old man said, "Now, looky here, boy; this is the pitifulest fix for a person to be in. We're run clean out of Arkansaw, and I ain't got no way to get back. My partner, he's got to have help, too; he's been selling an article that removes tartar from the teeth—and it does it, too, and generly removes the enamel along with it—but he's been telling the people it was a patent medicine, and that's where the trouble begun." The younger one broke in, "Well, what of it? It ain't my fault I couldn't make a living out of the legitimate drama. And I'd a been selling something different by this time if it warn't for him; he forced me into it." They were a sorry-looking pair, and I felt for them, though I didn't quite believe all their stories. They pleaded so hard, and looked so miserable, that I told them to come aboard. They thanked me over and over, and got their carpet-bags and climbed onto the raft. The woods were thick and dark, and it was getting late, so we pushed off and drifted down the river.

events.title: The Younger Con Man Claims Dukedom and Receives Royal Treatment
detailed_summary: The younger fugitive proposed to the older one that they should team up, an idea the older man was amenable to.
They then discussed their respective 'lines' of work, or rather, their various scams and professions.

The younger man listed his skills as a journeyman printer, dabbling in patent medicines, performing as a tragedy actor, practicing mesmerism and phrenology when opportunities arose, occasionally teaching 'singing-geography' school, and sometimes delivering lectures – essentially, anything that was not conventional work.

The older man mentioned his experience in 'doctoring,' particularly laying on of hands for ailments like cancer and paralysis, fortune-telling (especially when someone else could gather the necessary information for him), preaching, working at camp-meetings, and general missionary work.
Following a pause in conversation, the younger man sighed dramatically and began to lament his current circumstances, expressing sorrow at leading such a life and being 'degraded' into such company.
When the older man questioned his lament, the younger man delivered a self-pitying speech, claiming he had brought his downfall upon himself and deserved his current low state.
He then dramatically revealed what he termed 'the secret of my birth,' proclaiming himself to be, by rights, a duke.
Jim's eyes widened in astonishment, and Huck presumed his own did as well.

The younger man elaborated on his claim, stating he was the rightful Duke of Bridgewater, a lineal descendant of the eldest son of a Duke of Bridgewater who had fled to America. He asserted that the titles and estates had been unjustly seized by a second son, while the infant true duke (his ancestor) was ignored.
He portrayed himself as forlorn, hunted, despised, ragged, heartbroken, and degraded by his association with felons on a raft.
Both Jim and Huck felt immense pity for him. The 'Duke' suggested that acknowledging his rank would comfort him more than anything else.

They agreed to do so, and he instructed them to bow when addressing him, use titles such as 'Your Grace,' 'My Lord,' or 'Your Lordship,' and mentioned he wouldn't mind being called 'Bridgewater.' He also requested that one of them wait on him at dinner and perform any small tasks he desired.

Huck and Jim found these requests easy to fulfill. Throughout dinner, Jim attended to the 'Duke,' asking, 'Will yo’ Grace have some o’ dis or some o’ dat?', which clearly pleased the 'Duke' immensely.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All through dinner Jim stood around and waited on him, and says, “Will yo’ Grace have some o’ dis or some o’ dat?” and so on, and a body could see it was mighty pleasing to him.

events.text_segment:
“Old man,” said the young one, “I reckon we might double-team it together; what do you think?”
“I ain’t undisposed. What’s your line—mainly?”
“Jour printer by trade; do a little in patent medicines; theater-actor—tragedy, you know; take a turn to mesmerism and phrenology when there’s a chance; teach singing-geography school for a change; sling a lecture sometimes—oh, I do lots of things—most anything that comes handy, so it ain’t work. What’s your lay?”
“I’ve done considerble in the doctoring way in my time. Layin’ on o’ hands is my best holt—for cancer and paralysis, and sich things; and I k’n tell a fortune pretty good when I’ve got somebody along to find out the facts for me. Preachin’s my line, too, and workin’ camp-meetin’s, and missionaryin’ around.”
Nobody never said anything for a while; then the young man hove a sigh and says:
“Alas!”
“What ’re you alassin’ about?” says the baldhead.
“To think I should have lived to be leading such a life, and be degraded down into such company.” And he begun to wipe the corner of his eye with a rag.
“Dern your skin, ain’t the company good enough for you?” says the baldhead, pretty pert and uppish.
“Yes, it is good enough for me; it’s as good as I deserve; for who fetched me so low when I was so high? I did myself. I don’t blame you, gentlemen—far from it; I don’t blame anybody. I deserve it all. Let the cold world do its worst; one thing I know—there’s a grave somewhere for me. The world may go on just as it’s always done, and take everything from me—loved ones, property, everything; but it can’t take that. Some day I’ll lie down in it and forget it all, and my poor broken heart will be at rest.” He went on a-wiping.
“Drot your pore broken heart,” says the baldhead; “what are you heaving your pore broken heart at us f’r? We hain’t done nothing.”
“No, I know you haven’t. I ain’t blaming you, gentlemen. I brought myself down—yes, I did it myself. It’s right I should suffer—perfectly right—I don’t make any moan.”
“Brought you down from whar? Whar was you brought down from?”
“Ah, you would not believe me; the world never believes—let it pass—’tis no matter. The secret of my birth—”
“The secret of your birth! Do you mean to say—”
“Gentlemen,” says the young man, very solemn, “I will reveal it to you, for I feel I may have confidence in you. By rights I am a duke!”
Jim’s eyes bugged out when he heard that; and I reckon mine did, too. Then the baldhead says: “No! you can’t mean it?”
“Yes. My great-grandfather, eldest son of the Duke of Bridgewater, fled to this country about the end of the last century, to breathe the pure air of freedom; married here, and died, leaving a son, his own father dying about the same time. The second son of the late duke seized the titles and estates—the infant real duke was ignored. I am the lineal descendant of that infant—I am the rightful Duke of Bridgewater; and here am I, forlorn, torn from my high estate, hunted of men, despised by the cold world, ragged, worn, heart-broken, and degraded to the companionship of felons on a raft!”
Jim pitied him ever so much, and so did I. We tried to comfort him, but he said it warn’t much use, he couldn’t be much comforted; said if we was a mind to acknowledge him, that would do him more good than most anything else; so we said we would, if he would tell us how. He said we ought to bow when we spoke to him, and say “Your Grace,” or “My Lord,” or “Your Lordship”—and he wouldn’t mind it if we called him plain “Bridgewater,” which, he said, was a title anyway, and not a name; and one of us ought to wait on him at dinner, and do any little thing for him he wanted done.
Well, that was all easy, so we done it. All through dinner Jim stood around and waited on him, and says, “Will yo’ Grace have some o’ dis or some o’ dat?” and so on, and a body could see it was mighty pleasing to him.

events.title: The Older Con Man Claims to Be the Lost King of France
detailed_summary: The older man grew noticeably quiet and appeared uncomfortable witnessing the deferential treatment the 'Duke' was receiving.
He seemed to be contemplating something, and later in the afternoon, he addressed the 'Duke' (calling him 'Bilgewater'), stating that the 'Duke' wasn't the only one who had experienced such troubles.
He asserted that the 'Duke' was not unique in being wrongfully brought down from a high position or in having a secret of his birth, and then the older man himself began to cry.

When pressed, the older man, after securing a promise of trust from the 'Duke,' dramatically revealed his own secret: he declared himself to be the 'late Dauphin,' Louis XVII, son of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette, the rightful King of France.
This revelation caused Huck and Jim to stare in amazement. The 'Duke' expressed skepticism, particularly regarding the older man's age in relation to the historical Dauphin.

The older man attributed his aged appearance, gray hairs, and premature baldness to 'trouble,' presenting himself as the wandering, exiled, trampled-on, and suffering King of France, clad in blue jeans and misery.
Moved by his sorrowful display, Huck and Jim felt both pity and a sense of pride at having such an eminent personage with them. They began to comfort him as they had the 'Duke.'

The 'King' claimed that only death could truly relieve his suffering, but he admitted that being treated according to his royal rights often made him feel better. He requested that people kneel when speaking to him, always call him 'Your Majesty,' serve him first at meals, and not sit in his presence until invited.
Huck and Jim readily complied, bestowing royal honors upon him, which significantly cheered him up.

However, the 'Duke' became somewhat resentful of the new hierarchy and the attention the 'King' was receiving. Despite this, the 'King' acted very friendly towards the 'Duke,' mentioning that his (the King's) father had held the Duke's ancestors in high regard.

After the 'Duke' remained disgruntled for some time, the 'King' philosophically reasoned with him. He pointed out that they would likely be together on the raft for a long time, so being sour would only create discomfort. He emphasized that it wasn't his fault he wasn't born a duke, nor the 'Duke's' fault he wasn't born a king, so there was no use in worrying. He advocated for making the best of their situation and offered his hand in friendship.
The 'Duke' accepted this gesture, and Huck and Jim were greatly pleased, as it dispelled the tension and restored harmony on the raft, which they valued highly for peaceful coexistence.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It took away all the uncomfortableness and we felt mighty good over it, because it would a been a miserable business to have any unfriendliness on the raft; for what you want, above all things, on a raft, is for everybody to be satisfied, and feel right and kind towards the others.

events.text_segment:
But the old man got pretty silent by-and-by—didn’t have much to say, and didn’t look pretty comfortable over all that petting that was going on around that duke. He seemed to have something on his mind. So, along in the afternoon, he says:
“Looky here, Bilgewater,” he says, “I’m nation sorry for you, but you ain’t the only person that’s had troubles like that.”
“No?”
“No you ain’t. You ain’t the only person that’s ben snaked down wrongfully out’n a high place.”
“Alas!”
“No, you ain’t the only person that’s had a secret of his birth.” And, by jings, he begins to cry.
“Hold! What do you mean?”
“Bilgewater, kin I trust you?” says the old man, still sort of sobbing.
“To the bitter death!” He took the old man by the hand and squeezed it, and says, “That secret of your being: speak!”
“Bilgewater, I am the late Dauphin!”
You bet you, Jim and me stared this time. Then the duke says:
“You are what?”
“Yes, my friend, it is too true—your eyes is lookin’ at this very moment on the pore disappeared Dauphin, Looy the Seventeen, son of Looy the Sixteen and Marry Antonette.”
“You! At your age! No! You mean you’re the late Charlemagne; you must be six or seven hundred years old, at the very least.”
“Trouble has done it, Bilgewater, trouble has done it; trouble has brung these gray hairs and this premature balditude. Yes, gentlemen, you see before you, in blue jeans and misery, the wanderin’, exiled, trampled-on, and sufferin’ rightful King of France.”
Well, he cried and took on so that me and Jim didn’t know hardly what to do, we was so sorry—and so glad and proud we’d got him with us, too. So we set in, like we done before with the duke, and tried to comfort him. But he said it warn’t no use, nothing but to be dead and done with it all could do him any good; though he said it often made him feel easier and better for a while if people treated him according to his rights, and got down on one knee to speak to him, and always called him “Your Majesty,” and waited on him first at meals, and didn’t set down in his presence till he asked them. So Jim and me set to majestying him, and doing this and that and t’other for him, and standing up till he told us we might set down. This done him heaps of good, and so he got cheerful and comfortable. But the duke kind of soured on him, and didn’t look a bit satisfied with the way things was going; still, the king acted real friendly towards him, and said the duke’s great-grandfather and all the other Dukes of Bilgewater was a good deal thought of by his father, and was allowed to come to the palace considerable; but the duke stayed huffy a good while, till by-and-by the king says:
“Like as not we got to be together a blamed long time on this h-yer raft, Bilgewater, and so what’s the use o’ your bein’ sour? It’ll only make things oncomfortable. It ain’t my fault I warn’t born a duke, it ain’t your fault you warn’t born a king—so what’s the use to worry? Make the best o’ things the way you find ’em, says I—that’s my motto. This ain’t no bad thing that we’ve struck here—plenty grub and an easy life—come, give us your hand, Duke, and le’s all be friends.”
The duke done it, and Jim and me was pretty glad to see it. It took away all the uncomfortableness and we felt mighty good over it, because it would a been a miserable business to have any unfriendliness on the raft; for what you want, above all things, on a raft, is for everybody to be satisfied, and feel right and kind towards the others.

events.title: Huck's Astute Realization and Pragmatic Decision for Peace
detailed_summary: Huck quickly discerned that the two newcomers were not genuine royalty but were, in fact, common swindlers and deceivers.
Despite this realization, he decided not to reveal his knowledge or challenge their claims.
He concluded that maintaining silence and feigning belief was the most effective strategy to prevent arguments and avoid trouble.
He was willing to address them as kings and dukes if it helped maintain peace within their group, which he thought of as 'the family.'
Furthermore, he saw no benefit in informing Jim of his suspicions, so he kept this insight to himself.

Huck reflected on a lesson learned from his father, Pap: the most practical way to deal with people like the two con men was to allow them to have their own way, thus ensuring a smoother and less confrontational coexistence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It didn’t take me long to make up my mind that these liars warn’t no kings nor dukes at all, but just low-down humbugs and frauds.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If I never learnt nothing else out of pap, I learnt that the best way to get along with his kind of people is to let them have their own way.

events.text_segment: It didn’t take me long to make up my mind that these liars warn’t no kings nor dukes at all, but just low-down humbugs and frauds. But I never said nothing, never let on; kept it to myself; it’s the best way; then you don’t have no quarrels, and don’t get into no trouble. If they wanted us to call them kings and dukes, I hadn’t no objections, ’long as it would keep peace in the family; and it warn’t no use to tell Jim, so I didn’t tell him. If I never learnt nothing else out of pap, I learnt that the best way to get along with his kind of people is to let them have their own way.

events.title: Huck's Elaborate Lie and the Duke's Plan for Daytime Travel
detailed_summary: The duke and king questioned Huck about why the raft was covered and why they only traveled at night, asking if Jim was a runaway.
Huck deflected the question about Jim running south, which they agreed a runaway wouldn't do.
Huck then fabricated a lengthy story about his family from Pike County, Missouri, explaining that only he, his pa, and his brother Ike survived initially.
He continued the tale, claiming his pa intended to move them to his Uncle Ben's place near Orleans but was poor.
According to Huck's story, after finding a piece of raft, a steamboat accident killed his pa and young Ike, leaving only him and Jim.
He concluded by saying people constantly tried to take Jim, believing him to be a runaway, which is why they now travel only at night.
The duke announced he would devise a method that would allow them to travel during the daytime if desired, deferring the solution for the moment to avoid passing a nearby town in daylight.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They asked us considerable many questions; wanted to know what we covered up the raft that way for, and laid by in the daytime instead of running—was Jim a runaway nigger?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We’ll let it alone for to-day, because of course we don’t want to go by that town yonder in daylight—it mightn’t be healthy.”

events.text_segment:
They asked us considerable many questions; wanted to know what we covered up the raft that way for, and laid by in the daytime instead of running—was Jim a runaway nigger? Says I:
“Goodness sakes, would a runaway nigger run south?”
No, they allowed he wouldn’t. I had to account for things some way, so I says:
“My folks was living in Pike County, in Missouri, where I was born, and they all died off but me and pa and my brother Ike. Pa, he ’lowed he’d break up and go down and live with Uncle Ben, who’s got a little one-horse place on the river, forty-four mile below Orleans. Pa was pretty poor, and had some debts; so when he’d squared up there warn’t nothing left but sixteen dollars and our nigger, Jim. That warn’t enough to take us fourteen hundred mile, deck passage nor no other way. Well, when the river rose pa had a streak of luck one day; he ketched this piece of a raft; so we reckoned we’d go down to Orleans on it. Pa’s luck didn’t hold out; a steamboat run over the forrard corner of the raft one night, and we all went overboard and dove under the wheel; Jim and me come up all right, but pa was drunk, and Ike was only four years old, so they never come up no more. Well, for the next day or two we had considerable trouble, because people was always coming out in skiffs and trying to take Jim away from me, saying they believed he was a runaway nigger. We don’t run daytimes no more now; nights they don’t bother us.”
The duke says:
“Leave me alone to cipher out a way so we can run in the daytime if we want to. I’ll think the thing over—I’ll invent a plan that’ll fix it. We’ll let it alone for to-day, because of course we don’t want to go by that town yonder in daylight—it mightn’t be healthy.”

events.title: Dispute Over Sleeping Arrangements and the Duke's Theatrical Submission
detailed_summary: As evening approached, signs of a storm appeared, with darkening skies and heat lightning.
The duke and the king began to inspect the sleeping arrangements in the wigwam.
Huck's straw tick bed was noted as superior to Jim's corn-shuck tick, which was uncomfortable due to cobs and rustling.
The duke declared he would take Huck's better bed.
The king, however, asserted his higher rank, stating that a corn-shuck bed was unsuitable for him and ordered the duke to take it.
Huck and Jim felt a moment of anxiety, fearing another conflict between the two con men.
The duke then dramatically conceded, proclaiming it his fate to suffer oppression and misfortune, and that he would submit to taking the inferior bed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Towards night it begun to darken up and look like rain; the heat lightning was squirting around low down in the sky, and the leaves was beginning to shiver—it was going to be pretty ugly, it was easy to see that.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I am alone in the world—let me suffer; I can bear it.”

events.text_segment:
Towards night it begun to darken up and look like rain; the heat lightning was squirting around low down in the sky, and the leaves was beginning to shiver—it was going to be pretty ugly, it was easy to see that. So the duke and the king went to overhauling our wigwam, to see what the beds was like. My bed was a straw tick better than Jim’s, which was a corn-shuck tick; there’s always cobs around about in a shuck tick, and they poke into you and hurt; and when you roll over the dry shucks sound like you was rolling over in a pile of dead leaves; it makes such a rustling that you wake up. Well, the duke allowed he would take my bed; but the king allowed he wouldn’t. He says:
“I should a reckoned the difference in rank would a sejested to you that a corn-shuck bed warn’t just fitten for me to sleep on. Your Grace’ll take the shuck bed yourself.”
Jim and me was in a sweat again for a minute, being afraid there was going to be some more trouble amongst them; so we was pretty glad when the duke says:
“’Tis my fate to be always ground into the mire under the iron heel of oppression. Misfortune has broken my once haughty spirit; I yield, I submit; ’tis my fate. I am alone in the world—let me suffer; I can bear it.”

events.title: Navigating a Violent Storm and Sharing Watch Duties
detailed_summary: They departed once it was fully dark, with the king instructing them to stay mid-river and avoid showing a light until well past the town.
They successfully passed the town's lights at a distance.
Around ten o'clock, a severe storm with rain, wind, thunder, and lightning began.
The king and duke retreated into the wigwam for the night, assigning both Huck and Jim to remain on watch until the weather improved.
Huck, whose watch was until midnight, found the storm too spectacular to miss, observing the lightning illuminate the river and thrashing trees.
The waves sometimes nearly washed him off the raft, but being unclothed, he didn't mind.
The constant lightning helped them spot and avoid snags.
When it was time for Huck's middle watch, he was sleepy, so Jim kindly offered to cover the first part of it.
Huck found no space in the wigwam due to the sprawling king and duke, so he lay outside, unbothered by the warm rain.
Later, rising waves were about to prompt Jim to wake Huck, but Jim reconsidered, misjudging their danger; a large wave then washed Huck overboard, causing Jim great amusement.
Huck then took over the watch while Jim slept, and as the storm subsided, they found a hiding place for the raft at the first sign of daylight.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We got away as soon as it was good and dark.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I took the watch, and Jim he laid down and snored away; and by-and-by the storm let up for good and all; and the first cabin-light that showed, I rousted him out and we slid the raft into hiding quarters for the day.

events.text_segment:
We got away as soon as it was good and dark. The king told us to stand well out towards the middle of the river, and not show a light till we got a long ways below the town. We come in sight of the little bunch of lights by-and-by—that was the town, you know—and slid by, about a half a mile out, all right. When we was three-quarters of a mile below we hoisted up our signal lantern; and about ten o’clock it come on to rain and blow and thunder and lighten like everything; so the king told us to both stay on watch till the weather got better; then him and the duke crawled into the wigwam and turned in for the night. It was my watch below till twelve, but I wouldn’t a turned in anyway if I’d had a bed, because a body don’t see such a storm as that every day in the week, not by a long sight. My souls, how the wind did scream along! And every second or two there’d come a glare that lit up the white-caps for a half a mile around, and you’d see the islands looking dusty through the rain, and the trees thrashing around in the wind; then comes a h-whack!—bum! bum! bumble-umble-um-bum-bum-bum-bum—and the thunder would go rumbling and grumbling away, and quit—and then rip comes another flash and another sockdolager. The waves most washed me off the raft sometimes, but I hadn’t any clothes on, and didn’t mind. We didn’t have no trouble about snags; the lightning was glaring and flittering around so constant that we could see them plenty soon enough to throw her head this way or that and miss them.
I had the middle watch, you know, but I was pretty sleepy by that time, so Jim he said he would stand the first half of it for me; he was always mighty good that way, Jim was. I crawled into the wigwam, but the king and the duke had their legs sprawled around so there warn’t no show for me; so I laid outside—I didn’t mind the rain, because it was warm, and the waves warn’t running so high now. About two they come up again, though, and Jim was going to call me; but he changed his mind, because he reckoned they warn’t high enough yet to do any harm; but he was mistaken about that, for pretty soon all of a sudden along comes a regular ripper and washed me overboard. It most killed Jim a-laughing. He was the easiest nigger to laugh that ever was, anyway.
I took the watch, and Jim he laid down and snored away; and by-and-by the storm let up for good and all; and the first cabin-light that showed, I rousted him out and we slid the raft into hiding quarters for the day.

events.title: The Duke and King Devise Theatrical Scams
detailed_summary: After breakfast, the king and duke played cards before deciding to plan a

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The king got out an old ratty deck of cards after breakfast, and him and the duke played seven-up a while, five cents a game.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The king was satisfied; so the duke got out his book and read the parts over in the most splendid spread-eagle way, prancing around and acting at the same time, to show how it had got to be done; then he give the book to the king and told him to get his part by heart.

events.text_segment:
The king got out an old ratty deck of cards after breakfast, and him and the duke played seven-up a while, five cents a game. Then they got tired of it, and allowed they would “lay out a campaign,” as they called it. The duke went down into his carpet-bag, and fetched up a lot of little printed bills and read them out loud. One bill said, “The celebrated Dr. Armand de Montalban, of Paris,” would “lecture on the Science of Phrenology” at such and such a place, on the blank day of blank, at ten cents admission, and “furnish charts of character at twenty-five cents apiece.” The duke said that was him. In another bill he was the “world-renowned Shakespearian tragedian, Garrick the Younger, of Drury Lane, London.” In other bills he had a lot of other names and done other wonderful things, like finding water and gold with a “divining-rod,” “dissipating witch spells,” and so on. By-and-by he says:
“But the histrionic muse is the darling. Have you ever trod the boards, Royalty?”
“No,” says the king.
“You shall, then, before you’re three days older, Fallen Grandeur,” says the duke. “The first good town we come to we’ll hire a hall and do the sword fight in Richard III. and the balcony scene in Romeo and Juliet. How does that strike you?”
“I’m in, up to the hub, for anything that will pay, Bilgewater; but, you see, I don’t know nothing about play-actin’, and hain’t ever seen much of it. I was too small when pap used to have ’em at the palace. Do you reckon you can learn me?”
“Easy!”
“All right. I’m jist a-freezn’ for something fresh, anyway. Le’s commence right away.”
So the duke he told him all about who Romeo was and who Juliet was, and said he was used to being Romeo, so the king could be Juliet.
“But if Juliet’s such a young gal, duke, my peeled head and my white whiskers is goin’ to look oncommon odd on her, maybe.”
“No, don’t you worry; these country jakes won’t ever think of that. Besides, you know, you’ll be in costume, and that makes all the difference in the world; Juliet’s in a balcony, enjoying the moonlight before she goes to bed, and she’s got on her night-gown and her ruffled nightcap. Here are the costumes for the parts.”
He got out two or three curtain-calico suits, which he said was meedyevil armor for Richard III. and t’other chap, and a long white cotton nightshirt and a ruffled nightcap to match. The king was satisfied; so the duke got out his book and read the parts over in the most splendid spread-eagle way, prancing around and acting at the same time, to show how it had got to be done; then he give the book to the king and told him to get his part by heart.

events.title: Expedition to a Deserted Town and a Printing Office
detailed_summary: After dinner, the duke announced he had developed his plan to enable safe daytime travel for Jim and intended to go to a nearby small town to implement it.
The king decided to accompany him, hoping to find some opportunity for himself.
As they were out of coffee, Jim suggested Huck go with them in the canoe to purchase some.
Upon arrival, they found the town eerily deserted and quiet.
They encountered a sick black man who informed them that almost everyone was at a camp meeting about two miles away in the woods.
The king obtained directions and decided he would go to the camp meeting to try his luck, suggesting Huck could come too.
The duke stated his goal was to find a printing office, which they located above a carpenter shop; both were unlocked as the occupants were at the meeting.
The printing office was messy, with ink stains and posters of horses and runaway slaves on the walls.
The duke settled in at the printing office, while Huck and the king departed for the camp meeting.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was a little one-horse town about three mile down the bend, and after dinner the duke said he had ciphered out his idea about how to run in daylight without it being dangersome for Jim; so he allowed he would go down to the town and fix that thing.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So me and the king lit out for the camp-meeting.

events.text_segment:
There was a little one-horse town about three mile down the bend, and after dinner the duke said he had ciphered out his idea about how to run in daylight without it being dangersome for Jim; so he allowed he would go down to the town and fix that thing. The king allowed he would go, too, and see if he couldn’t strike something. We was out of coffee, so Jim said I better go along with them in the canoe and get some.
When we got there there warn’t nobody stirring; streets empty, and perfectly dead and still, like Sunday. We found a sick nigger sunning himself in a back yard, and he said everybody that warn’t too young or too sick or too old was gone to camp-meeting, about two mile back in the woods. The king got the directions, and allowed he’d go and work that camp-meeting for all it was worth, and I might go, too.
The duke said what he was after was a printing-office. We found it; a little bit of a concern, up over a carpenter shop—carpenters and printers all gone to the meeting, and no doors locked. It was a dirty, littered-up place, and had ink marks, and handbills with pictures of horses and runaway niggers on them, all over the walls. The duke shed his coat and said he was all right now. So me and the king lit out for the camp-meeting.

events.title: Huck Observes the Fervent Camp Meeting Atmosphere
detailed_summary: Huck and the king arrived at the camp meeting, hot and sweaty, finding a crowd of about a thousand people from the surrounding twenty miles.
The woods were filled with parked teams and wagons, with animals feeding and swatting flies.
There were makeshift sheds selling lemonade, gingerbread, watermelons, and corn.
Preaching took place under larger sheds, with benches made from log slabs and preachers on high platforms.
Huck observed the attire of the attendees: women in sun-bonnets and various frocks, some young men barefoot, and some children in only tow-linen shirts.
Some older women knitted, while young people courted discreetly.
In the first shed they entered, a preacher was leading a hymn line by line, with the large congregation singing rousingly.
The crowd grew increasingly animated, singing louder, with some beginning to groan and shout.
The preacher then began his sermon with great energy, moving across the platform, leaning forward, gesturing, and shouting his words.
He would periodically display his Bible, proclaiming it the key to salvation, eliciting shouts of 'Glory!' and 'Amen!' from the audience.
The sermon called for all sinners, the sick, the lame, the poor, and the suffering to come to the mourners' bench with broken spirits and contrite hearts.

The preacher's words became indistinguishable amidst the crowd's shouting and crying as people fervently pushed their way to the mourners' bench, overcome with emotion, eventually singing, shouting, and collapsing in a frenzy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We got there in about a half an hour fairly dripping, for it was a most awful hot day.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Folks got up everywheres in the crowd, and worked their way just by main strength to the mourners’ bench, with the tears running down their faces; and when all the mourners had got up there to the front benches in a crowd, they sung and shouted and flung themselves down on the straw, just crazy and wild.

events.text_segment:
We got there in about a half an hour fairly dripping, for it was a most awful hot day. There was as much as a thousand people there from twenty mile around. The woods was full of teams and wagons, hitched everywheres, feeding out of the wagon-troughs and stomping to keep off the flies. There was sheds made out of poles and roofed over with branches, where they had lemonade and gingerbread to sell, and piles of watermelons and green corn and such-like truck.
The preaching was going on under the same kinds of sheds, only they was bigger and held crowds of people. The benches was made out of outside slabs of logs, with holes bored in the round side to drive sticks into for legs. They didn’t have no backs. The preachers had high platforms to stand on at one end of the sheds. The women had on sun-bonnets; and some had linsey-woolsey frocks, some gingham ones, and a few of the young ones had on calico. Some of the young men was barefooted, and some of the children didn’t have on any clothes but just a tow-linen shirt. Some of the old women was knitting, and some of the young folks was courting on the sly.
The first shed we come to the preacher was lining out a hymn. He lined out two lines, everybody sung it, and it was kind of grand to hear it, there was so many of them and they done it in such a rousing way; then he lined out two more for them to sing—and so on. The people woke up more and more, and sung louder and louder; and towards the end some begun to groan, and some begun to shout. Then the preacher begun to preach, and begun in earnest, too; and went weaving first to one side of the platform and then the other, and then a-leaning down over the front of it, with his arms and his body going all the time, and shouting his words out with all his might; and every now and then he would hold up his Bible and spread it open, and kind of pass it around this way and that, shouting, “It’s the brazen serpent in the wilderness! Look upon it and live!” And people would shout out, “Glory!—A-a-men!” And so he went on, and the people groaning and crying and saying amen:
“Oh, come to the mourners’ bench! come, black with sin! (amen!) come, sick and sore! (amen!) come, lame and halt and blind! (amen!) come, pore and needy, sunk in shame! (a-a-men!) come, all that’s worn and soiled and suffering!—come with a broken spirit! come with a contrite heart! come in your rags and sin and dirt! the waters that cleanse is free, the door of heaven stands open—oh, enter in and be at rest!” (a-a-men! glory, glory hallelujah!)
And so on. You couldn’t make out what the preacher said any more, on account of the shouting and crying. Folks got up everywheres in the crowd, and worked their way just by main strength to the mourners’ bench, with the tears running down their faces; and when all the mourners had got up there to the front benches in a crowd, they sung and shouted and flung themselves down on the straw, just crazy and wild.

events.title: The King's 'Reformed Pirate' Con at the Camp Meeting
detailed_summary: Suddenly, the king began making loud noises and charged onto the preacher's platform; the preacher invited him to address the crowd.
The king then spun a tale, claiming to be a pirate for thirty years in the Indian Ocean whose crew had been decimated in a recent fight.
He said he had returned to recruit fresh men but was blessedly robbed and left penniless, an event he claimed led to his happy conversion.
He declared his intention to return to the Indian Ocean, despite his poverty, to dedicate his life to reforming pirates, asserting his unique ability to do so due to his familiarity with them.
He emotionally told the crowd that any pirate he converted would be instructed to credit the people of Pokeville camp meeting and the preacher.
The king's story brought himself and the entire audience to tears.
Someone suggested taking up a collection, and another proposed the king himself pass the hat, an idea endorsed by everyone, including the preacher.
The king moved through the crowd, collecting money while feigning tears, blessing the people, and being kissed by emotional young women.
He declined invitations to stay, citing his urgent mission to the Indian Ocean.
Back at the raft, the king counted his collection: eighty-seven dollars and seventy-five cents, plus a three-gallon jug of whisky he found.
He boasted that this day's earnings surpassed any from his supposed missionary work, claiming pirates were far more effective than heathens for swindling camp meetings.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, the first I knowed the king got a-going, and you could hear him over everybody; and next he went a-charging up on to the platform, and the preacher he begged him to speak to the people, and he done it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He said it warn’t no use talking, heathens don’t amount to shucks alongside of pirates to work a camp-meeting with.

events.text_segment:
Well, the first I knowed the king got a-going, and you could hear him over everybody; and next he went a-charging up on to the platform, and the preacher he begged him to speak to the people, and he done it. He told them he was a pirate—been a pirate for thirty years out in the Indian Ocean—and his crew was thinned out considerable last spring in a fight, and he was home now to take out some fresh men, and thanks to goodness he’d been robbed last night and put ashore off of a steamboat without a cent, and he was glad of it; it was the blessedest thing that ever happened to him, because he was a changed man now, and happy for the first time in his life; and, poor as he was, he was going to start right off and work his way back to the Indian Ocean, and put in the rest of his life trying to turn the pirates into the true path; for he could do it better than anybody else, being acquainted with all pirate crews in that ocean; and though it would take him a long time to get there without money, he would get there anyway, and every time he convinced a pirate he would say to him, “Don’t you thank me, don’t you give me no credit; it all belongs to them dear people in Pokeville camp-meeting, natural brothers and benefactors of the race, and that dear preacher there, the truest friend a pirate ever had!”
And then he busted into tears, and so did everybody. Then somebody sings out, “Take up a collection for him, take up a collection!” Well, a half a dozen made a jump to do it, but somebody sings out, “Let him pass the hat around!” Then everybody said it, the preacher too.
So the king went all through the crowd with his hat swabbing his eyes, and blessing the people and praising them and thanking them for being so good to the poor pirates away off there; and every little while the prettiest kind of girls, with the tears running down their cheeks, would up and ask him would he let them kiss him for to remember him by; and he always done it; and some of them he hugged and kissed as many as five or six times—and he was invited to stay a week; and everybody wanted him to live in their houses, and said they’d think it was an honor; but he said as this was the last day of the camp-meeting he couldn’t do no good, and besides he was in a sweat to get to the Indian Ocean right off and go to work on the pirates.
When we got back to the raft and he come to count up he found he had collected eighty-seven dollars and seventy-five cents. And then he had fetched away a three-gallon jug of whisky, too, that he found under a wagon when he was starting home through the woods. The king said, take it all around, it laid over any day he’d ever put in in the missionarying line. He said it warn’t no use talking, heathens don’t amount to shucks alongside of pirates to work a camp-meeting with.

events.title: The Duke's Printing Office Ventures and a Deceptive Plan for Jim
detailed_summary: The duke, initially pleased with his own day's work, felt overshadowed by the king's larger earnings.
He had earned four dollars printing two horse bills for farmers.
He also secured ten dollars' worth of advertisements for the local paper by offering a discount for advance payment, and three half-dollar subscriptions paid in advance in cash instead of goods.
He composed a three-verse poem titled “Yes, crush, cold world, this breaking heart,” and left it set up for printing in the paper at no charge, bringing his total earnings to nine and a half dollars.
The duke then revealed another printing job he hadn't charged for: a handbill for a runaway slave, featuring a picture and a $200 reward.
The description on the handbill perfectly matched Jim, falsely stating he ran away from a plantation near New Orleans.

The duke explained this was his plan to enable daytime travel: they could tie Jim up, claim they captured him upriver, show the handbill, and pretend they were too poor for steamboat travel and were taking him downriver on the raft to claim the reward.
He reasoned that ropes would be more convincing than handcuffs, fitting their story of poverty and maintaining

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The duke was thinking he’d been doing pretty well till the king come to show up, but after that he didn’t think so so much.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Ropes are the correct thing—we must preserve the unities, as we say on the boards.”

events.text_segment:
The duke was thinking he’d been doing pretty well till the king come to show up, but after that he didn’t think so so much. He had set up and printed off two little jobs for farmers in that printing-office—horse bills—and took the money, four dollars. And he had got in ten dollars’ worth of advertisements for the paper, which he said he would put in for four dollars if they would pay in advance—so they done it. The price of the paper was two dollars a year, but he took in three subscriptions for half a dollar apiece on condition of them paying him in advance; they were going to pay in cordwood and onions as usual, but he said he had just bought the concern and knocked down the price as low as he could afford it, and was going to run it for cash. He set up a little piece of poetry, which he made, himself, out of his own head—three verses—kind of sweet and saddish—the name of it was, “Yes, crush, cold world, this breaking heart”—and he left that all set up and ready to print in the paper, and didn’t charge nothing for it. Well, he took in nine dollars and a half, and said he’d done a pretty square day’s work for it.
Then he showed us another little job he’d printed and hadn’t charged for, because it was for us. It had a picture of a runaway nigger with a bundle on a stick over his shoulder, and “$200 reward” under it. The reading was all about Jim, and just described him to a dot. It said he run away from St. Jacques’ plantation, forty mile below New Orleans, last winter, and likely went north, and whoever would catch him and send him back he could have the reward and expenses.
“Now,” says the duke, “after to-night we can run in the daytime if we want to. Whenever we see anybody coming we can tie Jim hand and foot with a rope, and lay him in the wigwam and show this handbill and say we captured him up the river, and were too poor to travel on a steamboat, so we got this little raft on credit from our friends and are going down to get the reward. Handcuffs and chains would look still better on Jim, but it wouldn’t go well with the story of us being so poor. Too much like jewelry. Ropes are the correct thing—we must preserve the unities, as we say on the boards.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The duke was thinking he’d been doing pretty well till the king come to show up, but after that he didn’t think so so much. The king, he was a whole different kettle of fish, and a much bigger one at that. He had a way of taking over, of making himself the center of attention, and the duke, for all his airs and graces, found himself playing second fiddle. It wasn't that the king was smarter, not really. The duke reckoned he had more book-learning, more polish. But the king, he had a kind of low cunning, a shamelessness that the duke couldn't quite match. He'd lie with such conviction, such a pious look on his face, that folks just couldn't help but believe him, or at least feel too ashamed to doubt him.

Take the Royal Nonesuch, for instance. That was the duke's idea, mostly. He'd cooked up the handbills, the "Ladies and Children Not Admitted" part, thinking it would draw a crowd. And it did. But it was the king who really sold it, prancing out there nearly naked, painted all over, whooping and cavorting like a lunatic. The duke, he just introduced him, made a little speech. He felt a bit like a ringmaster presenting a particularly wild beast. And the money, well, the king had a knack for scooping up the lion's share of that too. He'd count it out, his eyes gleaming, and somehow the duke's portion always seemed a little lighter than it ought to be. He’d try to argue, sometimes, but the king would just look sorrowful and talk about the expenses, the bribes they had to pay, the cost of living for royalty, and the duke would usually back down, grumbling under his breath. It wasn't worth a real fight, not when they were in it together, adrift on that raft.

Then there was the Wilks affair. That was the king's grand scheme from the get-go. He'd heard about Peter Wilks dying and leaving a pile of money, and right away his mind started churning. The duke went along with it, played his part as the deaf and dumb brother, but he had his misgivings. It felt different from their usual scams, more serious, more likely to land them in real trouble. But the king, he was in his element, weeping and wailing over a man he'd never met, fooling those poor girls, and nearly getting away with all that gold. The duke had to admit, it was a masterful performance, even if it made his skin crawl a bit. He started to see that while he might be a duke, this old fraud was a king of con men, and there was a big difference in their ambition and their nerve. The duke was content with small grifts, a little here, a little there. The king, he wanted it all, and he didn't care who he stepped on to get it. It made the duke feel almost respectable by comparison, which was a strange thought indeed. He was still a scoundrel, no doubt about it, but next to the king, he felt like a mere apprentice, a journeyman rogue to the king's grand master of villainy. And that, he figured, was why the king always seemed to come out on top, even when the duke had the better ideas.

events.title: Agreement on the Duke's Plan and Cautious Departure
detailed_summary: Everyone on the raft agreed that the duke's plan involving the fake handbill was clever and would resolve the issue of traveling in daylight.
They anticipated that the duke's activities at the printing office might cause trouble in the small town, so they decided to travel a significant distance that night to be out of reach.
They remained hidden and quiet, waiting until nearly ten o'clock before carefully maneuvering the raft past the town, staying far from it.
They only raised their signal lantern once they were completely out of the town's sight.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We all said the duke was pretty smart, and there couldn’t be no trouble about running daytimes.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We laid low and kept still, and never shoved out till nearly ten o’clock; then we slid by, pretty wide away from the town, and didn’t hoist our lantern till we was clear out of sight of it.

events.text_segment:
We all said the duke was pretty smart, and there couldn’t be no trouble about running daytimes. We judged we could make miles enough that night to get out of the reach of the powwow we reckoned the duke’s work in the printing office was going to make in that little town; then we could boom right along if we wanted to.
We laid low and kept still, and never shoved out till nearly ten o’clock; then we slid by, pretty wide away from the town, and didn’t hoist our lantern till we was clear out of sight of it.

events.title: Jim's Weariness of 'Royalty' and the King's Forgotten French
detailed_summary: At four in the morning, when Jim woke Huck for his watch, Jim expressed a hope that they wouldn't encounter any more kings on their journey.
Jim commented that having one or two kings was sufficient, noting that their current king was often very drunk, and the duke wasn't much better.
Huck then learned that Jim had attempted to persuade the king to speak French, simply because Jim was curious to hear it.
The king, however, had claimed that he had been in America for such a long time and had experienced so many difficulties that he had forgotten how to speak French.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When Jim called me to take the watch at four in the morning, he says:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I found Jim had been trying to get him to talk French, so he could hear what it was like; but he said he had been in this country so long, and had so much trouble, he’d forgot it.

events.text_segment:
When Jim called me to take the watch at four in the morning, he says:
“Huck, does you reck’n we gwyne to run acrost any mo’ kings on dis trip?”
“No,” I says, “I reckon not.”
“Well,” says he, “dat’s all right, den. I doan’ mine one er two kings, but dat’s enough. Dis one’s powerful drunk, en de duke ain’ much better.”
I found Jim had been trying to get him to talk French, so he could hear what it was like; but he said he had been in this country so long, and had so much trouble, he’d forgot it.

events.title: Theatrical Rehearsals and Mishaps on the Raft
detailed_summary: After sunrise, the King and the Duke, looking worse for wear, were invigorated by a swim in the river.
Following breakfast, the King settled on the raft's edge, dangling his legs in the water, lit his pipe, and began memorizing his lines for Romeo and Juliet.
The Duke and King then rehearsed together, with the Duke meticulously instructing the King on the proper delivery for each of Romeo's speeches.

The Duke stressed that Romeo's words should be spoken softly and with a sense of longing and illness, fitting for addressing Juliet, whom he described as a sweet young girl, not to be addressed with a booming voice.
Subsequently, they practiced a sword fight using long swords fashioned by the Duke from oak laths, with the Duke portraying Richard III, creating an impressive spectacle as they moved about the raft.
The practice session was interrupted when the King stumbled and fell into the river.
After this incident, they ceased their rehearsal, rested, and engaged in conversation about various adventures they had experienced on the river in the past.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was after sun-up now, but we went right on and didn’t tie up.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But by-and-by the king tripped and fell overboard, and after that they took a rest, and had a talk about all kinds of adventures they’d had in other times along the river.

events.text_segment:
It was after sun-up now, but we went right on and didn’t tie up. The king and the duke turned out by-and-by looking pretty rusty; but after they’d jumped overboard and took a swim it chippered them up a good deal. After breakfast the king he took a seat on the corner of the raft, and pulled off his boots and rolled up his britches, and let his legs dangle in the water, so as to be comfortable, and lit his pipe, and went to getting his Romeo and Juliet by heart. When he had got it pretty good, him and the duke begun to practice it together. The duke had to learn him over and over again how to say every speech; and he made him sigh, and put his hand on his heart, and after a while he said he done it pretty well; “only,” he says, “you mustn’t bellow out Romeo! that way, like a bull—you must say it soft and sick and languishy, so—R-o-o-meo! that is the idea; for Juliet’s a dear sweet mere child of a girl, you know, and she doesn’t bray like a jackass.”
Well, next they got out a couple of long swords that the duke made out of oak laths, and begun to practice the sword fight—the duke called himself Richard III.; and the way they laid on and pranced around the raft was grand to see. But by-and-by the king tripped and fell overboard, and after that they took a rest, and had a talk about all kinds of adventures they’d had in other times along the river.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The king and the duke were powerful hungry, and Jim and me too. We took out some of our breakfast that was left over from the night before, and eat it on a log, and watched the river. The king got out his fiddle and played a little, but it warn’t no use; we didn’t feel gay. There warn’t no more popular music for us. It was a mighty solemn day. We was all pretty glum. We had a long ways to go yet.

We run across a lot of islands, and now and then a wood-yard and a cabin; but we didn’t see no people. We saw a steamboat coughing along up stream, so we hid our raft in a willer towhead till it was by and gone. Then we come out and went on. About the middle of the day we passed a little log cabin, now and then, away down yonder, close to the river bank, and we could see smoke curling up out of the chimney. We could see the people, too, moving about in their yards. We was getting hungry again.

The king said he reckoned we would land and forage around a little. He said he didn’t believe we could make any more money on the raft, and he was tired of this sort of life, anyway. The duke said he was tired of it too, and he guessed he wouldn’t fool away no more time with it. So we all agreed that we would land at the first convenient place and try to find something to eat. We kept a lookout, and pretty soon we see a little opening in the woods, and we steered in there and tied up. We was all glad to get ashore.

events.title: Crafting an Encore: The Duke's "Hamlet" and the King's Enthusiasm
detailed_summary: Following their dinner, the Duke expressed a desire to elevate their show to a first-class production, suggesting the addition of more content, particularly something for encores.
The King, unfamiliar with the term "onkores," prompted the Duke to provide an explanation.
The Duke outlined his plan for an encore, intending to perform either the Highland fling or a sailor's hornpipe, and then decided the King should perform Hamlet's soliloquy.
The King was perplexed by the mention of "Hamlet's soliloquy."
The Duke lauded the soliloquy as Shakespeare's most renowned and emotionally powerful piece, asserting it always captivated audiences.

As he didn't have the full text, possessing only one volume of Shakespeare, the Duke endeavored to reconstruct the soliloquy from memory, pacing back and forth with exaggerated expressions of thought and emotion.
He then delivered his pieced-together version with dramatic flair, involving intense gestures and vocalizations, a performance that Huck, the narrator, also learned by heart.
The King was greatly taken with the speech and quickly became proficient in delivering it with impressive vigor and dramatic effect, seemingly a natural fit for the role.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After dinner the duke says:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Well, the old man he liked that speech, and he mighty soon got it so he could do it first rate. It seemed like he was just born for it; and when he had his hand in and was excited, it was perfectly lovely the way he would rip and tear and rair up behind when he was getting it off.

events.text_segment:
After dinner the duke says:
“Well, Capet, we’ll want to make this a first-class show, you know, so I guess we’ll add a little more to it. We want a little something to answer encores with, anyway.”
“What’s onkores, Bilgewater?”
The duke told him, and then says:
“I’ll answer by doing the Highland fling or the sailor’s hornpipe; and you—well, let me see—oh, I’ve got it—you can do Hamlet’s soliloquy.”
“Hamlet’s which?”
“Hamlet’s soliloquy, you know; the most celebrated thing in Shakespeare. Ah, it’s sublime, sublime! Always fetches the house. I haven’t got it in the book—I’ve only got one volume—but I reckon I can piece it out from memory. I’ll just walk up and down a minute, and see if I can call it back from recollection’s vaults.”
So he went to marching up and down, thinking, and frowning horrible every now and then; then he would hoist up his eyebrows; next he would squeeze his hand on his forehead and stagger back and kind of moan; next he would sigh, and next he’d let on to drop a tear. It was beautiful to see him. By-and-by he got it. He told us to give attention. Then he strikes a most noble attitude, with one leg shoved forwards, and his arms stretched away up, and his head tilted back, looking up at the sky; and then he begins to rip and rave and grit his teeth; and after that, all through his speech, he howled, and spread around, and swelled up his chest, and just knocked the spots out of any acting ever I see before. This is the speech—I learned it, easy enough, while he was learning it to the king:
To be, or not to be; that is the bare bodkin
That makes calamity of so long life;
For who would fardels bear, till Birnam Wood do come to Dunsinane,
But that the fear of something after death
Murders the innocent sleep,
Great nature’s second course,
And makes us rather sling the arrows of outrageous fortune
Than fly to others that we know not of.
There’s the respect must give us pause:
Wake Duncan with thy knocking! I would thou couldst;
For who would bear the whips and scorns of time,
The oppressor’s wrong, the proud man’s contumely,
The law’s delay, and the quietus which his pangs might take.
In the dead waste and middle of the night, when churchyards yawn
In customary suits of solemn black,
But that the undiscovered country from whose bourne no traveler returns,
Breathes forth contagion on the world,
And thus the native hue of resolution, like the poor cat i’ the adage,
Is sicklied o’er with care.
And all the clouds that lowered o’er our housetops,
With this regard their currents turn awry,
And lose the name of action.
’Tis a consummation devoutly to be wished.
But soft you, the fair Ophelia:
Ope not thy ponderous and marble jaws.
But get thee to a nunnery—go!
Well, the old man he liked that speech, and he mighty soon got it so he could do it first rate. It seemed like he was just born for it; and when he had his hand in and was excited, it was perfectly lovely the way he would rip and tear and rair up behind when he was getting it off.
