events.title: Profits of Deceit, Royal Gloating, and Huck's Cynical Discourse on Kingship
detailed_summary: The group traveled approximately ten miles downriver before feeling secure enough to light a lamp and prepare supper.
During their meal, the King and the Duke reveled in their successful deception of the townspeople and their narrow escape from the planned retaliation.

The Duke elaborated on his strategy, explaining he had anticipated that the first audience, feeling swindled, would encourage others to attend, and that the third night would be when the duped townsfolk would attempt their revenge.
He humorously speculated on how the townspeople were now 'enjoying' their opportunity for payback with the rotten provisions they had brought.
The narrator reveals that the conmen had amassed a total of four hundred and sixty-five dollars from their three-night theatrical scam, a sum that astonished Huck.
Later, after the King and Duke had fallen asleep, Jim expressed his bewilderment to Huck regarding the uncouth behavior of these self-proclaimed 'kings'.
Huck responded that their actions were not surprising to him, as he believed such conduct was inherent to all royalty.
Jim contended that their companions were merely common swindlers, not actual kings.
Huck, however, maintained his cynical view, asserting that, based on his understanding, most kings were essentially rapscallions.

To illustrate his point, Huck launched into a comically inaccurate and anachronistic diatribe about various historical monarchs, portraying all of them, especially Henry VIII, as villains of the highest order, conflating figures, events, and timelines.
He concluded that their current 'king' was comparatively mild and that one simply had to make allowances for kings, whom he described as a 'mighty ornery lot' due to their upbringing.
Jim then remarked on the unpleasant body odor of their 'king'.
Huck philosophized that all kings likely smelled bad and that history offered no remedies for such a royal trait.
Jim acknowledged that the Duke was perhaps slightly more tolerable in some respects.
Huck concurred that a duke was different, but not significantly so, deeming their Duke a rather poor specimen, particularly when inebriated.
Jim declared he had had enough of both 'kings' and 'dukes'.
Huck shared Jim's exhaustion but pragmatically noted they were stuck with the conmen and needed to remember their true nature and tolerate them, wistfully wishing for a country devoid of kings.

Huck reflected internally on the futility of revealing to Jim that the King and Duke were frauds, believing it would serve no purpose and that their behavior was, in his eyes, indistinguishable from that of genuine royalty.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We never showed a light till we was about ten mile below the village.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: What was the use to tell Jim these warn’t real kings and dukes? It wouldn’t a done no good; and, besides, it was just as I said: you couldn’t tell them from the real kind.

events.text_segment:
We never showed a light till we was about ten mile below the village. Then we lit up and had a supper, and the king and the duke fairly laughed their bones loose over the way they’d served them people. The duke says:
“Greenhorns, flatheads! I knew the first house would keep mum and let the rest of the town get roped in; and I knew they’d lay for us the third night, and consider it was their turn now. Well, it is their turn, and I’d give something to know how much they’d take for it. I would just like to know how they’re putting in their opportunity. They can turn it into a picnic if they want to—they brought plenty provisions.”
Them rapscallions took in four hundred and sixty-five dollars in that three nights. I never see money hauled in by the wagon-load like that before. By-and-by, when they was asleep and snoring, Jim says:
“Don’t it s’prise you de way dem kings carries on, Huck?”
“No,” I says, “it don’t.”
“Why don’t it, Huck?”
“Well, it don’t, because it’s in the breed. I reckon they’re all alike.”
“But, Huck, dese kings o’ ourn is reglar rapscallions; dat’s jist what dey is; dey’s reglar rapscallions.”
“Well, that’s what I’m a-saying; all kings is mostly rapscallions, as fur as I can make out.”
“Is dat so?”
“You read about them once—you’ll see. Look at Henry the Eight; this’n ’s a Sunday-school Superintendent to him. And look at Charles Second, and Louis Fourteen, and Louis Fifteen, and James Second, and Edward Second, and Richard Third, and forty more; besides all them Saxon heptarchies that used to rip around so in old times and raise Cain. My, you ought to seen old Henry the Eight when he was in bloom. He was a blossom. He used to marry a new wife every day, and chop off her head next morning. And he would do it just as indifferent as if he was ordering up eggs. ‘Fetch up Nell Gwynn,’ he says. They fetch her up. Next morning, ‘Chop off her head!’ And they chop it off. ‘Fetch up Jane Shore,’ he says; and up she comes, Next morning, ‘Chop off her head’—and they chop it off. ‘Ring up Fair Rosamun.’ Fair Rosamun answers the bell. Next morning, ‘Chop off her head.’ And he made every one of them tell him a tale every night; and he kept that up till he had hogged a thousand and one tales that way, and then he put them all in a book, and called it Domesday Book—which was a good name and stated the case. You don’t know kings, Jim, but I know them; and this old rip of ourn is one of the cleanest I’ve struck in history. Well, Henry he takes a notion he wants to get up some trouble with this country. How does he go at it—give notice?—give the country a show? No. All of a sudden he heaves all the tea in Boston Harbor overboard, and whacks out a declaration of independence, and dares them to come on. That was his style—he never give anybody a chance. He had suspicions of his father, the Duke of Wellington. Well, what did he do? Ask him to show up? No—drownded him in a butt of mamsey, like a cat. S’pose people left money laying around where he was—what did he do? He collared it. S’pose he contracted to do a thing, and you paid him, and didn’t set down there and see that he done it—what did he do? He always done the other thing. S’pose he opened his mouth—what then? If he didn’t shut it up powerful quick he’d lose a lie every time. That’s the kind of a bug Henry was; and if we’d a had him along ’stead of our kings he’d a fooled that town a heap worse than ourn done. I don’t say that ourn is lambs, because they ain’t, when you come right down to the cold facts; but they ain’t nothing to that old ram, anyway. All I say is, kings is kings, and you got to make allowances. Take them all around, they’re a mighty ornery lot. It’s the way they’re raised.”
“But dis one do smell so like de nation, Huck.”
“Well, they all do, Jim. We can’t help the way a king smells; history don’t tell no way.”
“Now de duke, he’s a tolerble likely man in some ways.”
“Yes, a duke’s different. But not very different. This one’s a middling hard lot for a duke. When he’s drunk, there ain’t no near-sighted man could tell him from a king.”
“Well, anyways, I doan’ hanker for no mo’ un um, Huck. Dese is all I kin stan’.”
“It’s the way I feel, too, Jim. But we’ve got them on our hands, and we got to remember what they are, and make allowances. Sometimes I wish we could hear of a country that’s out of kings.”
What was the use to tell Jim these warn’t real kings and dukes? It wouldn’t a done no good; and, besides, it was just as I said: you couldn’t tell them from the real kind.

events.title: Jim's Profound Grief and the Heartbreaking Story of His Daughter 'Lizabeth's Deafness
detailed_summary: Huck went to sleep, and Jim, in a common act of kindness, allowed him to sleep through his scheduled watch.
Upon waking at daybreak, Huck discovered Jim sitting with his head bowed between his knees, audibly moaning and expressing deep sorrow.
Huck intuitively understood that Jim was overwhelmed with homesickness and grief for his wife and children, from whom he had never before been separated.

Huck reflected on Jim's profound affection for his family, believing it to be as strong as that of white individuals for their own kin—a realization he found somewhat unnatural by societal standards, yet accepted as true.

He noted that Jim often mourned this way during the night when he presumed Huck was asleep, lamenting for his 'Po’ little ’Lizabeth' and 'po’ little Johnny,' and voicing his fear of never seeing them again. Huck privately acknowledged Jim as a 'mighty good nigger'.
On this particular morning, Huck initiated a conversation with Jim about his family.

Jim explained that his acute sadness was triggered by a sound he had heard from the riverbank, which vividly reminded him of an incident where he had treated his young daughter, ’Lizabeth, with unintentional cruelty.
He recounted that ’Lizabeth, who was only about four years old at the time, had endured a severe illness, scarlet fever.
Sometime after her recovery, Jim had instructed her to close a door. When she didn’t comply, merely smiling up at him, he became irritated.
He repeated his command more forcefully, but she remained unresponsive, still smiling.
Consumed by anger, Jim struck her forcefully on the side of her head, causing her to fall.
He then left the room for approximately ten minutes. Upon his return, he found the door still ajar and ’Lizabeth standing near it, looking down and crying silently.
As he was about to confront her again, a sudden gust of wind slammed the inward-opening door shut with a loud 'ker-blam!' right behind the child.
To Jim's profound shock, ’Lizabeth did not react in any way to the loud noise.
This lack of response deeply unsettled Jim. Overcome with a strange feeling, he cautiously crept around, quietly opened the door, and positioned himself behind her.
He then suddenly shouted 'pow!' as loudly as he possibly could, directly behind her head.
When ’Lizabeth still showed no reaction, the devastating truth dawned on Jim. He burst into tears, embraced her, and cried out for the Lord's forgiveness, knowing he could never forgive himself.
He then revealed to Huck, with immense sorrow, that his little daughter was completely deaf and dumb, and he had tragically mistreated her without understanding her condition.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I went to sleep, and Jim didn’t call me when it was my turn.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Oh, she was plumb deef en dumb, Huck, plumb deef en dumb—en I’d ben a-treat’n her so!”

events.text_segment:
I went to sleep, and Jim didn’t call me when it was my turn. He often done that. When I waked up just at daybreak, he was sitting there with his head down betwixt his knees, moaning and mourning to himself. I didn’t take notice nor let on. I knowed what it was about. He was thinking about his wife and his children, away up yonder, and he was low and homesick; because he hadn’t ever been away from home before in his life; and I do believe he cared just as much for his people as white folks does for their’n. It don’t seem natural, but I reckon it’s so. He was often moaning and mourning that way nights, when he judged I was asleep, and saying, “Po’ little ’Lizabeth! po’ little Johnny! it’s mighty hard; I spec’ I ain’t ever gwyne to see you no mo’, no mo’!” He was a mighty good nigger, Jim was.
But this time I somehow got to talking to him about his wife and young ones; and by-and-by he says:
“What makes me feel so bad dis time ’uz bekase I hear sumpn over yonder on de bank like a whack, er a slam, while ago, en it mine me er de time I treat my little ’Lizabeth so ornery. She warn’t on’y ’bout fo’ year ole, en she tuck de sk’yarlet fever, en had a powful rough spell; but she got well, en one day she was a-stannin’ aroun’, en I says to her, I says:
“‘Shet de do’.’
“She never done it; jis’ stood dah, kiner smilin’ up at me. It make me mad; en I says agin, mighty loud, I says:
“‘Doan’ you hear me?—shet de do’!’
“She jis stood de same way, kiner smilin’ up. I was a-bilin’! I says:
“‘I lay I make you mine!’
“En wid dat I fetch’ her a slap side de head dat sont her a-sprawlin’. Den I went into de yuther room, en ’uz gone ’bout ten minutes; en when I come back dah was dat do’ a-stannin’ open yit, en dat chile stannin’ mos’ right in it, a-lookin’ down and mournin’, en de tears runnin’ down. My, but I wuz mad! I was a-gwyne for de chile, but jis’ den—it was a do’ dat open innerds—jis’ den, ’long come de wind en slam it to, behine de chile, ker-blam!—en my lan’, de chile never move’! My breff mos’ hop outer me; en I feel so—so—I doan’ know how I feel. I crope out, all a-tremblin’, en crope aroun’ en open de do’ easy en slow, en poke my head in behine de chile, sof’ en still, en all uv a sudden I says pow! jis’ as loud as I could yell. She never budge! Oh, Huck, I bust out a-cryin’ en grab her up in my arms, en say, ‘Oh, de po’ little thing! De Lord God Amighty fogive po’ ole Jim, kaze he never gwyne to fogive hisself as long’s he live!’ Oh, she was plumb deef en dumb, Huck, plumb deef en dumb—en I’d ben a-treat’n her so!”

events.title: Jim's "Sick Arab" Disguise
detailed_summary: The duke and the king began strategizing to exploit the two nearby towns.
Jim voiced his discomfort about being tied up in the wigwam all day, a necessary precaution to maintain his facade as a runaway slave if discovered alone.
The duke, described as exceptionally intelligent, quickly conceived a plan to alleviate Jim's situation.
He dressed Jim in a King Lear costume, consisting of a long calico gown, a white horse-hair wig, and whiskers.
The duke then used theater paint to color Jim's face, hands, ears, and neck a deathly, solid blue, making him resemble a man who had been drowned for nine days.
Huck found Jim's transformed appearance to be the most horrifying sight he had ever witnessed.
To complete the ruse, the duke wrote a sign on a shingle stating, "Sick Arab—but harmless when not out of his head," and placed it in front of the wigwam.
Jim expressed satisfaction with this arrangement, finding it far preferable to being tied up daily and constantly on edge.
The duke instructed Jim to act freely but, if anyone approached, to jump out of the wigwam, behave erratically, and howl like a wild animal, expecting this to frighten people away.
Huck mused that Jim's ghastly appearance alone would likely be sufficient to deter anyone, even before any howling.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Next day, towards night, we laid up under a little willow tow-head out in the middle, where there was a village on each side of the river, and the duke and the king begun to lay out a plan for working them towns.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Why, he didn’t only look like he was dead, he looked considerable more than that.

events.text_segment:
Next day, towards night, we laid up under a little willow tow-head out in the middle, where there was a village on each side of the river, and the duke and the king begun to lay out a plan for working them towns. Jim he spoke to the duke, and said he hoped it wouldn’t take but a few hours, because it got mighty heavy and tiresome to him when he had to lay all day in the wigwam tied with the rope. You see, when we left him all alone we had to tie him, because if anybody happened on to him all by himself and not tied it wouldn’t look much like he was a runaway nigger, you know. So the duke said it was kind of hard to have to lay roped all day, and he’d cipher out some way to get around it.
He was uncommon bright, the duke was, and he soon struck it. He dressed Jim up in King Lear’s outfit—it was a long curtain-calico gown, and a white horse-hair wig and whiskers; and then he took his theater paint and painted Jim’s face and hands and ears and neck all over a dead, dull, solid blue, like a man that’s been drownded nine days. Blamed if he warn’t the horriblest looking outrage I ever see. Then the duke took and wrote out a sign on a shingle so:
Sick Arab—but harmless when not out of his head.
And he nailed that shingle to a lath, and stood the lath up four or five foot in front of the wigwam. Jim was satisfied. He said it was a sight better than lying tied a couple of years every day, and trembling all over every time there was a sound. The duke told him to make himself free and easy, and if anybody ever come meddling around, he must hop out of the wigwam, and carry on a little, and fetch a howl or two like a wild beast, and he reckoned they would light out and leave him alone. Which was sound enough judgment; but you take the average man, and he wouldn’t wait for him to howl. Why, he didn’t only look like he was dead, he looked considerable more than that.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Jim he spoke to the duke, and said he hoped it warn't going to be long 'fore he could buy his children back and have them free. The duke said it warn't no use to bother the king about it now, for he was thinking. So Jim he was quiet.

But the king he got the blues, and told the duke he reckoned he'd be a goner if he didn't have a revival. The duke told him to cheer up, and said they'd have a revival, sure enough. So the king he cheered up.

But the duke he was thinking. He said he reckoned they could turn out a pretty good crowd in them towns. He said he reckoned they could take in four or five hundred dollars easy. He said he reckoned they could work them towns till they was clean wore out.

The king he said he reckoned so too. He said he reckoned they could make a clean sweep. He said he reckoned they could skin them towns from head to foot.

So they laid out their plans. They was going to play the 'Royal Nonesuch' first. Then they was going to play the 'Burning Shame.' Then they was going to play the 'Bloody Hand.' Then they was going to play the 'Pirate's Doom.' Then they was going to play the 'Tragedy of the Unfortunate Maiden.' Then they was going to play the 'Noble Duke of Bridgewater.' Then they was going to play the 'Lost Heir.' Then they was going to play the 'Sick Arab.' Then they was going to play the 'Tame Leopard.' Then they was going to play the 'Learned Pig.' Then they was going to play the 'Wild Man of Borneo.' Then they was going to play the 'What Is It?'

They reckoned they could keep that up for three weeks, and then they'd have to lay by and rest up. They reckoned they could make about three thousand dollars in that time. They reckoned they could live like kings.

So they was all pretty well satisfied. They went to work and got their things ready. They got out their old bills and pasted them up on the trees and fences. They got out their old costumes and furbished them up. They got out their old swords and pistols and cleaned them up. They got out their old drums and fifes and tuned them up. They was all ready for business.

events.title: New Scams Considered and a River Encounter
detailed_summary: The con men contemplated repeating their lucrative "Nonesuch" performance but decided against it, fearing word of their previous scam might have spread.
Failing to settle on a suitable new project, the duke resolved to spend some time devising a plan for the Arkansas village.
The king, conversely, decided to go to the other village without a specific plan, trusting in what Huck sardonically calls "Providence" (implying the devil) to lead him to profit.
Having recently purchased new outfits, the king donned his and instructed Huck to do the same.
The king's new black attire strikingly transformed his appearance from that of a disreputable vagrant to a man of apparent dignity and piety, leading Huck to marvel at the effect of clothing.

While Jim readied the canoe, the king, citing his respectable new look, proposed they arrive at the village via a steamboat, ostensibly coming from a larger city like St. Louis or Cincinnati, to create a more impressive entrance.
Huck, enthusiastic about a steamboat ride, paddled towards the vessel located about three miles upriver.
Along the way, they observed a young, seemingly naive country fellow sitting on a log, wiping sweat due to the intense heat, with two large carpet-bags next to him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: These rapscallions wanted to try the Nonesuch again, because there was so much money in it, but they judged it wouldn’t be safe, because maybe the news might a worked along down by this time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Pretty soon we come to a nice innocent-looking young country jake setting on a log swabbing the sweat off of his face, for it was powerful warm weather; and he had a couple of big carpet-bags by him.

events.text_segment:
These rapscallions wanted to try the Nonesuch again, because there was so much money in it, but they judged it wouldn’t be safe, because maybe the news might a worked along down by this time. They couldn’t hit no project that suited exactly; so at last the duke said he reckoned he’d lay off and work his brains an hour or two and see if he couldn’t put up something on the Arkansaw village; and the king he allowed he would drop over to t’other village without any plan, but just trust in Providence to lead him the profitable way—meaning the devil, I reckon. We had all bought store clothes where we stopped last; and now the king put his’n on, and he told me to put mine on. I done it, of course. The king’s duds was all black, and he did look real swell and starchy. I never knowed how clothes could change a body before. Why, before, he looked like the orneriest old rip that ever was; but now, when he’d take off his new white beaver and make a bow and do a smile, he looked that grand and good and pious that you’d say he had walked right out of the ark, and maybe was old Leviticus himself. Jim cleaned up the canoe, and I got my paddle ready. There was a big steamboat laying at the shore away up under the point, about three mile above the town—been there a couple of hours, taking on freight. Says the king:
“Seein’ how I’m dressed, I reckon maybe I better arrive down from St. Louis or Cincinnati, or some other big place. Go for the steamboat, Huckleberry; we’ll come down to the village on her.”
I didn’t have to be ordered twice to go and take a steamboat ride. I fetched the shore a half a mile above the village, and then went scooting along the bluff bank in the easy water. Pretty soon we come to a nice innocent-looking young country jake setting on a log swabbing the sweat off of his face, for it was powerful warm weather; and he had a couple of big carpet-bags by him.

events.title: The King Gathers Intelligence on the Wilks Family
detailed_summary: The king directed Huck to bring the canoe to the shore where the young man was.
Upon asking the young man's destination, he learned the man was traveling to New Orleans via the steamboat.
The king invited the young man aboard their canoe, instructing Huck (whom he called "Adolphus") to assist with the luggage.
The young man expressed gratitude for the help, noting the difficulty of carrying his bags in the hot weather.
When asked about his own plans, the king falsely claimed to have recently arrived at the other village and was now heading a few miles upriver to visit an old friend on a farm.
The young man mentioned he had initially mistaken the king for a Mr. Wilks, who was expected, but then doubted it because the king was paddling upstream.
The king introduced himself as "Reverend Elexander Blodgett" and feigned sympathy for Mr. Wilks possibly having missed something significant.
The young man clarified that Peter Wilks had not missed out on any inheritance but had missed the opportunity to see his brother Peter before he died.

He elaborated that Peter Wilks had been desperate to see his brothers, Harvey (a preacher in England) and William (who was deaf and dumb), before his death. Peter had not seen Harvey since their boyhood and had never met William.
The young man explained Peter's loneliness following the deaths of his brother George and George's wife, which left George's young daughters (Mary Jane, Susan, and Joanna) somewhat orphaned.
Peter, who was elderly and ill, had avoided writing a formal will but left a letter for Harvey detailing the location of his money and instructions for dividing the property to care for his nieces.
The young man conveyed that Harvey Wilks lived in Sheffield, England, and might not have received the letter or had sufficient time to travel.

The king persistently questioned the young man, acquiring details about the Wilks nieces' ages (Mary Jane, nineteen; Susan, fifteen; Joanna, about fourteen and having a hare-lip) and the local friends, like Deacon Lot Hovey and Levi Bell, who would look after them.

The king continued his inquiries until he had extracted comprehensive information about everyone in the town, the Wilks family, Peter's tanning business, George's carpentry profession, and Harvey's role as a dissenting minister.
He learned that Peter Wilks was relatively wealthy, possessing houses, land, and an estimated three to four thousand dollars in hidden cash.
The young man revealed that Peter Wilks had died the previous night, and his funeral was scheduled for the middle of the next day.
The king responded with pious remarks about mortality and the importance of being prepared, to which the young man concurred, quoting his mother.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Run her nose in shore,” says the king.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Ma used to always say that.”

events.text_segment:
“Run her nose in shore,” says the king. I done it. “Wher’ you bound for, young man?”
“For the steamboat; going to Orleans.”
“Git aboard,” says the king. “Hold on a minute, my servant ’ll he’p you with them bags. Jump out and he’p the gentleman, Adolphus”—meaning me, I see.
I done so, and then we all three started on again. The young chap was mighty thankful; said it was tough work toting his baggage such weather. He asked the king where he was going, and the king told him he’d come down the river and landed at the other village this morning, and now he was going up a few mile to see an old friend on a farm up there. The young fellow says:
“When I first see you I says to myself, ‘It’s Mr. Wilks, sure, and he come mighty near getting here in time.’ But then I says again, ‘No, I reckon it ain’t him, or else he wouldn’t be paddling up the river.’ You ain’t him, are you?”
“No, my name’s Blodgett—Elexander Blodgett—Reverend Elexander Blodgett, I s’pose I must say, as I’m one o’ the Lord’s poor servants. But still I’m jist as able to be sorry for Mr. Wilks for not arriving in time, all the same, if he’s missed anything by it—which I hope he hasn’t.”
“Well, he don’t miss any property by it, because he’ll get that all right; but he’s missed seeing his brother Peter die—which he mayn’t mind, nobody can tell as to that—but his brother would a give anything in this world to see him before he died; never talked about nothing else all these three weeks; hadn’t seen him since they was boys together—and hadn’t ever seen his brother William at all—that’s the deef and dumb one—William ain’t more than thirty or thirty-five. Peter and George were the only ones that come out here; George was the married brother; him and his wife both died last year. Harvey and William’s the only ones that’s left now; and, as I was saying, they haven’t got here in time.”
“Did anybody send ’em word?”
“Oh, yes; a month or two ago, when Peter was first took; because Peter said then that he sorter felt like he warn’t going to get well this time. You see, he was pretty old, and George’s g’yirls was too young to be much company for him, except Mary Jane, the red-headed one; and so he was kinder lonesome after George and his wife died, and didn’t seem to care much to live. He most desperately wanted to see Harvey—and William, too, for that matter—because he was one of them kind that can’t bear to make a will. He left a letter behind for Harvey, and said he’d told in it where his money was hid, and how he wanted the rest of the property divided up so George’s g’yirls would be all right—for George didn’t leave nothing. And that letter was all they could get him to put a pen to.”
“Why do you reckon Harvey don’t come? Wher’ does he live?”
“Oh, he lives in England—Sheffield—preaches there—hasn’t ever been in this country. He hasn’t had any too much time—and besides he mightn’t a got the letter at all, you know.”
“Too bad, too bad he couldn’t a lived to see his brothers, poor soul. You going to Orleans, you say?”
“Yes, but that ain’t only a part of it. I’m going in a ship, next Wednesday, for Ryo Janeero, where my uncle lives.”
“It’s a pretty long journey. But it’ll be lovely; wisht I was a-going. Is Mary Jane the oldest? How old is the others?”
“Mary Jane’s nineteen, Susan’s fifteen, and Joanna’s about fourteen—that’s the one that gives herself to good works and has a hare-lip.”
“Poor things! to be left alone in the cold world so.”
“Well, they could be worse off. Old Peter had friends, and they ain’t going to let them come to no harm. There’s Hobson, the Babtis’ preacher; and Deacon Lot Hovey, and Ben Rucker, and Abner Shackleford, and Levi Bell, the lawyer; and Dr. Robinson, and their wives, and the widow Bartley, and—well, there’s a lot of them; but these are the ones that Peter was thickest with, and used to write about sometimes, when he wrote home; so Harvey ’ll know where to look for friends when he gets here.”
Well, the old man went on asking questions till he just fairly emptied that young fellow. Blamed if he didn’t inquire about everybody and everything in that blessed town, and all about the Wilkses; and about Peter’s business—which was a tanner; and about George’s—which was a carpenter; and about Harvey’s—which was a dissentering minister; and so on, and so on. Then he says:
“What did you want to walk all the way up to the steamboat for?”
“Because she’s a big Orleans boat, and I was afeard she mightn’t stop there. When they’re deep they won’t stop for a hail. A Cincinnati boat will, but this is a St. Louis one.”
“Was Peter Wilks well off?”
“Oh, yes, pretty well off. He had houses and land, and it’s reckoned he left three or four thousand in cash hid up som’ers.”
“When did you say he died?”
“I didn’t say, but it was last night.”
“Funeral to-morrow, likely?”
“Yes, ’bout the middle of the day.”
“Well, it’s all terrible sad; but we’ve all got to go, one time or another. So what we want to do is to be prepared; then we’re all right.”
“Yes, sir, it’s the best way. Ma used to always say that.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
```text
"Run her nose in shore," says the king. I done it. "Where was you going, young man?"
"To New Orleans, sir, on the steamboat when she comes," says the young man.
"Well, step aboard our craft, then," says the king. "Adolphus," he says to me, "take the gentleman's valise."
"Thank you kindly, sir," says the young man. "It's powerful hot, and these traps are a hefty load."
The king, he asks, "And where might you be from, and what's your business hereabouts?"
"Oh, I've just come down from the other village," says the king, smooth as butter. "Just arrived, in fact. Heading a few miles upriver to see an old friend on his farm."
The young man looked a bit puzzled. "Well, I did take you for Mr. Wilks, who's expected, but then I reckoned not, seeing as you were paddling upstream."
"Wilks?" says the king, perking up. "My name is Reverend Elexander Blodgett. Poor Mr. Wilks, has he missed out on something significant?"
"Oh, no, not missed out on any inheritance, if that's what you mean," the young man explained. "He's missed seeing his brother Peter before he died. Peter Wilks, he was desperate to see his brothers, Harvey – that's a preacher over in England – and William, who's deaf and dumb. Peter hadn't seen Harvey since they were boys, and he'd never laid eyes on William at all."
The young man went on, "You see, Peter was mighty lonesome after his brother George and George's wife passed, leaving George's girls – Mary Jane, Susan, and Joanna – sort of orphaned. Peter, he was old and ailing, and he didn't get around to a formal will, but he left a letter for Harvey, telling him where the money was hid and how to divide the property to care for his nieces."
"Sheffield, England, you say Harvey Wilks lives?" the king prodded. "Might be he didn't get the letter, or didn't have time to make the journey."
The king kept at him, asking all sorts of questions. "And these nieces, how old might they be?"
"Mary Jane, she's nineteen," the young man said. "Susan's fifteen, and Joanna, she's about fourteen and has a hare-lip. Good folks around here, like Deacon Lot Hovey and Mr. Levi Bell, the lawyer, they'll look after them."
The king didn't let up, nosing into every little detail about everyone in town, the Wilks family, how Peter had a tanning business, and George was a carpenter, and Harvey was a dissenting minister. He found out Peter Wilks was pretty well off, with houses and land, and maybe three or four thousand dollars in cash stashed away.
"And when did this Peter Wilks pass on?" the king asked, his voice all solemn.
"Last night, sir," said the young man. "Funeral's set for the middle of tomorrow."
"Ah, the uncertainty of life!" says the king, shaking his head like a parson. "We must all be prepared. It is a solemn thought."
"Indeed, sir," the young man agreed. "My mother always said so."
```

events.title: The King Devises the Wilks Impersonation Scheme
detailed_summary: Upon reaching the steamboat, they found it had nearly completed its loading and departed shortly thereafter, much to Huck's disappointment as he missed his ride.
The king then instructed Huck to paddle another mile to a more isolated location along the river.

Once ashore, the king ordered Huck to return immediately, locate the duke (even if it meant crossing to the other side of the river), and bring him along with the new carpet-bags, ensuring the duke was presentably dressed.
Huck, though silent, perceived the king's emerging plan.
When Huck returned with the duke, they concealed the canoe.
The king then sat down with the duke and recounted every detail about the Wilks family and their circumstances, just as the young man had told him.
During this explanation, the king practiced speaking with an English accent, which Huck observed he managed quite convincingly for someone of his background.
The king then queried the duke on his ability to portray a deaf and dumb individual.
The duke confidently asserted his capability, mentioning prior acting experience in such roles.
Having settled their roles, they began to wait for a steamboat that could take them to the village connected with the Wilks family.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When we struck the boat she was about done loading, and pretty soon she got off.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So then they waited for a steamboat.

events.text_segment:
When we struck the boat she was about done loading, and pretty soon she got off. The king never said nothing about going aboard, so I lost my ride, after all. When the boat was gone the king made me paddle up another mile to a lonesome place, and then he got ashore and says:
“Now hustle back, right off, and fetch the duke up here, and the new carpet-bags. And if he’s gone over to t’other side, go over there and git him. And tell him to git himself up regardless. Shove along, now.”
I see what he was up to; but I never said nothing, of course. When I got back with the duke we hid the canoe, and then they set down on a log, and the king told him everything, just like the young fellow had said it—every last word of it. And all the time he was a-doing it he tried to talk like an Englishman; and he done it pretty well, too, for a slouch. I can’t imitate him, and so I ain’t a-going to try to; but he really done it pretty good. Then he says:
“How are you on the deef and dumb, Bilgewater?”
The duke said, leave him alone for that; said he had played a deef and dumb person on the histronic boards. So then they waited for a steamboat.

events.title: Arrival at the Village and Start of the Wilks Deception
detailed_summary: Around mid-afternoon, after a few unsuitable small boats passed, a large steamboat appeared from further upriver, which they successfully hailed.
The steamboat dispatched its yawl, and they boarded; it was a vessel from Cincinnati.
The crew was initially furious upon learning the king and duke only wanted a short journey of four or five miles and threatened not to land them.
The king calmly negotiated, arguing that if they were willing to pay a dollar per mile each for yawl transport, the steamboat could surely accommodate them.
The crew eventually agreed and transported them ashore at the village in the yawl.
As they landed, a group of about two dozen men gathered to meet the arriving yawl.
The king inquired if any of the gentlemen could direct him to the residence of Mr. Peter Wilks.
The townsmen exchanged knowing looks, and one of them gently informed the king that they could only show him where Peter Wilks *had* lived as of the previous evening.

Reacting instantaneously, the king put on a dramatic display of grief, collapsing against the informant, placing his chin on the man's shoulder, and wailing about their "poor brother" whom they supposedly never got to see.
He then turned, still blubbering, and made a series of exaggerated hand gestures to the duke, feigning communication with a deaf person.
The duke played his part by dropping a carpet-bag and bursting into tears, contributing to the fraudulent spectacle of sorrow.
Huck internally condemned the duo as the most accomplished con artists he had ever encountered.
The townspeople, completely deceived by the performance, offered their sympathies and kind words.
They assisted the con men by carrying their carpet-bags up the hill, allowing the frauds to lean on them for support while they cried, and shared details about Peter Wilks's final hours.
The king, in turn, relayed this information to the supposedly deaf duke using more hand signs, and both men continued their ostentatious mourning as if deeply bereaved.
Huck concluded his observation of the scene with a profound sense of shame for humanity.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: About the middle of the afternoon a couple of little boats come along, but they didn’t come from high enough up the river; but at last there was a big one, and they hailed her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was enough to make a body ashamed of the human race.

events.text_segment:
About the middle of the afternoon a couple of little boats come along, but they didn’t come from high enough up the river; but at last there was a big one, and they hailed her. She sent out her yawl, and we went aboard, and she was from Cincinnati; and when they found we only wanted to go four or five mile they was booming mad, and gave us a cussing, and said they wouldn’t land us. But the king was ca’m. He says:
“If gentlemen kin afford to pay a dollar a mile apiece to be took on and put off in a yawl, a steamboat kin afford to carry ’em, can’t it?”
So they softened down and said it was all right; and when we got to the village they yawled us ashore. About two dozen men flocked down when they see the yawl a-coming, and when the king says:
“Kin any of you gentlemen tell me wher’ Mr. Peter Wilks lives?” they give a glance at one another, and nodded their heads, as much as to say, “What d’ I tell you?” Then one of them says, kind of soft and gentle:
“I’m sorry sir, but the best we can do is to tell you where he did live yesterday evening.”
Sudden as winking the ornery old cretur went an to smash, and fell up against the man, and put his chin on his shoulder, and cried down his back, and says:
“Alas, alas, our poor brother—gone, and we never got to see him; oh, it’s too, too hard!”
Then he turns around, blubbering, and makes a lot of idiotic signs to the duke on his hands, and blamed if he didn’t drop a carpet-bag and bust out a-crying. If they warn’t the beatenest lot, them two frauds, that ever I struck.
Well, the men gathered around and sympathized with them, and said all sorts of kind things to them, and carried their carpet-bags up the hill for them, and let them lean on them and cry, and told the king all about his brother’s last moments, and the king he told it all over again on his hands to the duke, and both of them took on about that dead tanner like they’d lost the twelve disciples. Well, if ever I struck anything like it, I’m a nigger. It was enough to make a body ashamed of the human race.

events.title: The Frauds' Arrival and Feigned Mourning
detailed_summary: News of the "uncles'" arrival spreads rapidly through the town, drawing a large and expectant crowd to the Wilks family home.

The three Wilks sisters, Mary Jane, Susan, and Joanna (referred to as "hare-lip"), are at the door, and Mary Jane, described as exceptionally beautiful and radiant with joy, eagerly embraces the King.
Joanna similarly embraces the Duke, and the emotional reunion moves many onlookers, especially women, to tears of happiness.
The King subtly signals the Duke, and together they approach Peter Wilks's coffin, which is placed on two chairs in a corner, adopting an exaggerated air of solemnity.
The crowd respectfully makes way for them, and a hush falls over the room, with men removing their hats in deference.
Upon looking into the coffin, the King and Duke erupt into an extremely loud and theatrical display of weeping, a performance the narrator finds overdone.
Their feigned sorrow is so potent that it causes widespread weeping among the assembled townspeople, making the atmosphere palpably damp.
The two conmen then kneel beside the coffin, pretending to pray silently, a gesture that further intensifies the crowd's emotional outburst, with everyone, including the Wilks sisters, sobbing aloud.
Many women in the crowd approach the grieving sisters, offering solemn kisses on their foreheads and tearful, skyward glances as gestures of profound sympathy before moving away, still sobbing.
The narrator expresses his deep disgust at the entire manipulative spectacle orchestrated by the King and Duke.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The news was all over town in two minutes, and you could see the people tearing down on the run from every which way, some of them putting on their coats as they come.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I never see anything so disgusting.

events.text_segment:
The news was all over town in two minutes, and you could see the people tearing down on the run from every which way, some of them putting on their coats as they come. Pretty soon we was in the middle of a crowd, and the noise of the tramping was like a soldier march. The windows and dooryards was full; and every minute somebody would say, over a fence:
“Is it them?”
And somebody trotting along with the gang would answer back and say:
“You bet it is.”
When we got to the house the street in front of it was packed, and the three girls was standing in the door. Mary Jane was red-headed, but that don’t make no difference, she was most awful beautiful, and her face and her eyes was all lit up like glory, she was so glad her uncles was come. The king he spread his arms, and Mary Jane she jumped for them, and the hare-lip jumped for the duke, and there they had it! Everybody most, leastways women, cried for joy to see them meet again at last and have such good times.
Then the king he hunched the duke private—I see him do it—and then he looked around and see the coffin, over in the corner on two chairs; so then him and the duke, with a hand across each other’s shoulder, and t’other hand to their eyes, walked slow and solemn over there, everybody dropping back to give them room, and all the talk and noise stopping, people saying “Sh!” and all the men taking their hats off and drooping their heads, so you could a heard a pin fall. And when they got there they bent over and looked in the coffin, and took one sight, and then they bust out a-crying so you could a heard them to Orleans, most; and then they put their arms around each other’s necks, and hung their chins over each other’s shoulders; and then for three minutes, or maybe four, I never see two men leak the way they done. And, mind you, everybody was doing the same; and the place was that damp I never see anything like it. Then one of them got on one side of the coffin, and t’other on t’other side, and they kneeled down and rested their foreheads on the coffin, and let on to pray all to themselves. Well, when it come to that it worked the crowd like you never see anything like it, and everybody broke down and went to sobbing right out loud—the poor girls, too; and every woman, nearly, went up to the girls, without saying a word, and kissed them, solemn, on the forehead, and then put their hand on their head, and looked up towards the sky, with the tears running down, and then busted out and went off sobbing and swabbing, and give the next woman a show. I never see anything so disgusting.

events.title: The King's Mawkish Speech and a Moment of Genuine Song
detailed_summary: After a while, the King steps forward and begins a tearful, rambling speech.
He describes the great sorrow he and his "brother" (the Duke) feel for having lost their relative and for missing the chance to see him alive after their arduous four-thousand-mile journey.
He claims, however, that this trial is made sweeter and holier by the sympathy and tears of the assembled well-wishers.
The King then offers thanks on behalf of himself and his brother, stating that words are too inadequate to express their deep gratitude, a sentiment the narrator finds nauseatingly insincere.
He concludes his oration with a pious "Amen" and then dramatically resumes his loud crying.
As soon as the King finishes speaking, someone in the crowd spontaneously starts singing the doxology.
Everyone present joins in with great enthusiasm, and the music fills the room, creating a genuinely warm and uplifting atmosphere.

The narrator observes that music is a positive force and notes how effectively this heartfelt singing refreshed the mood after the King's insincere emotional display, which he describes as "soul-butter and hogwash."

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, by-and-by the king he gets up and comes forward a little, and works himself up and slobbers out a speech, all full of tears and flapdoodle about its being a sore trial for him and his poor brother to lose the diseased, and to miss seeing diseased alive after the long journey of four thousand mile, but it’s a trial that’s sweetened and sanctified to us by this dear sympathy and these holy tears, and so he thanks them out of his heart and out of his brother’s heart, because out of their mouths they can’t, words being too weak and cold, and all that kind of rot and slush, till it was just sickening; and then he blubbers out a pious goody-goody Amen, and turns himself loose and goes to crying fit to bust.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Music is a good thing; and after all that soul-butter and hogwash I never see it freshen up things so, and sound so honest and bully.

events.text_segment:
Well, by-and-by the king he gets up and comes forward a little, and works himself up and slobbers out a speech, all full of tears and flapdoodle about its being a sore trial for him and his poor brother to lose the diseased, and to miss seeing diseased alive after the long journey of four thousand mile, but it’s a trial that’s sweetened and sanctified to us by this dear sympathy and these holy tears, and so he thanks them out of his heart and out of his brother’s heart, because out of their mouths they can’t, words being too weak and cold, and all that kind of rot and slush, till it was just sickening; and then he blubbers out a pious goody-goody Amen, and turns himself loose and goes to crying fit to bust.
And the minute the words were out of his mouth somebody over in the crowd struck up the doxolojer, and everybody joined in with all their might, and it just warmed you up and made you feel as good as church letting out. Music is a good thing; and after all that soul-butter and hogwash I never see it freshen up things so, and sound so honest and bully.

events.title: Crafting an Inner Circle and Displaying "Knowledge"
detailed_summary: The King resumes speaking, inviting a select group of Peter Wilks's closest friends to join him and his nieces for supper that evening and to participate in the vigil for the deceased.

He recites a list of names—Rev. Mr. Hobson, Deacon Lot Hovey, Mr. Ben Rucker, Abner Shackleford, Levi Bell, Dr. Robinson, their wives, and the Widow Bartley—claiming these were individuals Peter held dear and frequently mentioned in his letters.

The narrator notes that Rev. Hobson and Dr. Robinson were currently elsewhere in town (the doctor attending a sick man, the preacher offering spiritual guidance), and Lawyer Bell was away in Louisville.
The remaining invited guests who are present come forward to greet the King, shake his hand, and engage him in conversation.

They also shake hands with the Duke, who continues his portrayal of a deaf and mute individual, communicating through hand signs and nonsensical "goo-goo" sounds, which the townspeople accept with naive smiles and nods.
The King proceeds to impress the gathering by casually mentioning various local people by name and recalling minor past events concerning the town, George's family, or Peter himself.

He consistently implies that Peter Wilks had conveyed all this information to him through letters, but the narrator reveals this to be a lie, stating that the King had actually gleaned all these details from the young man they had encountered on the river journey to the steamboat.

events.text_segment:
Then the king begins to work his jaw again, and says how him and his nieces would be glad if a few of the main principal friends of the family would take supper here with them this evening, and help set up with the ashes of the diseased; and says if his poor brother laying yonder could speak he knows who he would name, for they was names that was very dear to him, and mentioned often in his letters; and so he will name the same, to wit, as follows, vizz.:—Rev. Mr. Hobson, and Deacon Lot Hovey, and Mr. Ben Rucker, and Abner Shackleford, and Levi Bell, and Dr. Robinson, and their wives, and the widow Bartley.
Rev. Hobson and Dr. Robinson was down to the end of the town a-hunting together—that is, I mean the doctor was shipping a sick man to t’other world, and the preacher was pinting him right. Lawyer Bell was away up to Louisville on business. But the rest was on hand, and so they all come and shook hands with the king and thanked him and talked to him; and then they shook hands with the duke and didn’t say nothing, but just kept a-smiling and bobbing their heads like a passel of sapheads whilst he made all sorts of signs with his hands and said “Goo-goo—goo-goo-goo” all the time, like a baby that can’t talk.
So the king he blattered along, and managed to inquire about pretty much everybody and dog in town, by his name, and mentioned all sorts of little things that happened one time or another in the town, or to George’s family, or to Peter. And he always let on that Peter wrote him the things; but that was a lie: he got every blessed one of them out of that young flathead that we canoed up to the steamboat.

Deacon Hovey said he was dead broke, and didn't have a cent to his name, and he was afraid he wouldn't be able to come, either; but the king said, 'Never mind, deacon, we'll send a carriage for you.' The rest said they'd come. So then the king told the undertaker to despatch word to them, and then he told him to bring out the coffin. The undertaker done it, and me and the king and the duke and the niggers took a hand and carried it out and set it on a couple of chairs in the front room, and then the king and the duke spread a sheet over it and put on it a little Bible and a hymn-book, and then the king he took a seat at one end of the coffin and the duke at the other, and they waited.

events.title: The Inheritance, a Shortfall, and a Cover-Up
detailed_summary: Mary Jane retrieves a letter left by her father, which the King reads aloud, punctuating the reading with feigned tears.
The will bequeaths the family home and $3,000 in gold to the three Wilks sisters.
It also leaves the tanyard (a profitable business), along with other houses and land valued at about $7,000, and an additional $3,000 in gold to Harvey (the King) and William (the Duke).
Crucially, the letter states that $6,000 in cash is hidden in the cellar.
The King and Duke declare their intention to retrieve this money immediately to demonstrate their transparency and honesty, instructing Huck to accompany them with a candle.
After closing the cellar door behind them, they locate the bag of gold coins, a sight that causes the King's eyes to gleam with delight.
The King exclaims to the Duke that this current deception surpasses their previous "Nonesuch" scam in profitability.
The Duke agrees, and they playfully handle the gold coins.
The King philosophizes that being brothers to a wealthy deceased man and representing foreign heirs is their ideal line of work, attributing their success to trusting Providence.
Instead of accepting the sum on trust, they meticulously count the money and find it is $415 short of the $6,000 mentioned in the will.
The King expresses frustration over the missing amount.
The Duke speculates that the sick Peter Wilks might have made a mistake in his accounting and suggests they simply ignore the discrepancy.
The King, however, insists on maintaining an appearance of being "awful square and open," fearing that presenting less than the full amount upstairs would arouse suspicion.
The Duke then cleverly proposes they make up the deficit using money from their own pockets, likely proceeds from their "Nonesuch" performances.
The King praises the Duke's ingenuity, and they pool their gold to bring the total to exactly $6,000, though it nearly depletes their funds.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then Mary Jane she fetched the letter her father left behind, and the king he read it out loud and cried over it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It most busted them, but they made up the six thousand clean and clear.

events.text_segment:
Then Mary Jane she fetched the letter her father left behind, and the king he read it out loud and cried over it. It give the dwelling-house and three thousand dollars, gold, to the girls; and it give the tanyard (which was doing a good business), along with some other houses and land (worth about seven thousand), and three thousand dollars in gold to Harvey and William, and told where the six thousand cash was hid down cellar. So these two frauds said they’d go and fetch it up, and have everything square and above-board; and told me to come with a candle. We shut the cellar door behind us, and when they found the bag they spilt it out on the floor, and it was a lovely sight, all them yaller-boys. My, the way the king’s eyes did shine! He slaps the duke on the shoulder and says:
“Oh, this ain’t bully nor noth’n! Oh, no, I reckon not! Why, Bilji, it beats the Nonesuch, don’t it?”
The duke allowed it did. They pawed the yaller-boys, and sifted them through their fingers and let them jingle down on the floor; and the king says:
“It ain’t no use talkin’; bein’ brothers to a rich dead man and representatives of furrin heirs that’s got left is the line for you and me, Bilge. Thish yer comes of trust’n to Providence. It’s the best way, in the long run. I’ve tried ’em all, and ther’ ain’t no better way.”
Most everybody would a been satisfied with the pile, and took it on trust; but no, they must count it. So they counts it, and it comes out four hundred and fifteen dollars short. Says the king:
“Dern him, I wonder what he done with that four hundred and fifteen dollars?”
They worried over that awhile, and ransacked all around for it. Then the duke says:
“Well, he was a pretty sick man, and likely he made a mistake—I reckon that’s the way of it. The best way’s to let it go, and keep still about it. We can spare it.”
“Oh, shucks, yes, we can spare it. I don’t k’yer noth’n ’bout that—it’s the count I’m thinkin’ about. We want to be awful square and open and above-board here, you know. We want to lug this h-yer money up stairs and count it before everybody—then ther’ ain’t noth’n suspicious. But when the dead man says ther’s six thous’n dollars, you know, we don’t want to—”
“Hold on,” says the duke. “Le’s make up the deffisit,” and he begun to haul out yaller-boys out of his pocket.
“It’s a most amaz’n’ good idea, duke—you have got a rattlin’ clever head on you,” says the king. “Blest if the old Nonesuch ain’t a heppin’ us out agin,” and he begun to haul out yaller-jackets and stack them up.
It most busted them, but they made up the six thousand clean and clear.

events.title: A "Generous" Public Gift to Cement Trust
detailed_summary: The Duke suggests another clever idea: they should go upstairs, count the money in front of everyone, and then present it all to the Wilks girls.
The King is overjoyed by this proposal, calling it a "dazzling idea" and the ultimate deceptive maneuver ("boss dodge") that will effectively silence any potential doubters.
Once upstairs, with everyone gathered around a table, the King meticulously counts the $6,000, arranging it into twenty neat piles of $300 each, while the onlookers watch with eager anticipation.
After counting, he gathers the money back into the bag and prepares for another speech.
The King proclaims that his deceased brother, Peter, was generous to those left behind.
He asserts that Peter would have been even more generous to his beloved, orphaned daughters if he hadn't been afraid of hurting the feelings of his dear brothers, William (the Duke) and himself.
He then rhetorically questions what kind of brothers would obstruct such generosity or what kind of uncles would effectively "rob" these sweet, vulnerable girls.
To feign consultation, the King turns to the Duke and makes a series of hand gestures.
The Duke, after a moment of feigned confusion, appears to understand and jumps up, goo-gooing joyfully and hugging the King repeatedly.

The King then announces that the Duke's enthusiastic reaction confirms their shared sentiment and, addressing Mary Jane, Susan, and Joanna, dramatically gives them the entire $6,000, declaring it a gift from their departed father.
Mary Jane rushes to the King, while Susan and Joanna go to the Duke, resulting in another round of effusive hugging and kissing.
The assembled crowd, deeply moved and with tears in their eyes, crowds around the conmen, shaking their hands vigorously and exclaiming praise for their perceived goodness and generosity.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Say,” says the duke, “I got another idea. Le’s go up stairs and count this money, and then take and give it to the girls.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “You dear good souls!—how lovely!—how could you!”

events.text_segment:
“Say,” says the duke, “I got another idea. Le’s go up stairs and count this money, and then take and give it to the girls.”
“Good land, duke, lemme hug you! It’s the most dazzling idea ’at ever a man struck. You have cert’nly got the most astonishin’ head I ever see. Oh, this is the boss dodge, ther’ ain’t no mistake ’bout it. Let ’em fetch along their suspicions now if they want to—this’ll lay ’em out.”
When we got up-stairs everybody gethered around the table, and the king he counted it and stacked it up, three hundred dollars in a pile—twenty elegant little piles. Everybody looked hungry at it, and licked their chops. Then they raked it into the bag again, and I see the king begin to swell himself up for another speech. He says:
“Friends all, my poor brother that lays yonder has done generous by them that’s left behind in the vale of sorrers. He has done generous by these yer poor little lambs that he loved and sheltered, and that’s left fatherless and motherless. Yes, and we that knowed him knows that he would a done more generous by ’em if he hadn’t ben afeard o’ woundin’ his dear William and me. Now, wouldn’t he? Ther’ ain’t no question ’bout it in my mind. Well, then, what kind o’ brothers would it be that ’d stand in his way at sech a time? And what kind o’ uncles would it be that ’d rob—yes, rob—sech poor sweet lambs as these ’at he loved so at sech a time? If I know William—and I think I do—he—well, I’ll jest ask him.” He turns around and begins to make a lot of signs to the duke with his hands, and the duke he looks at him stupid and leather-headed a while; then all of a sudden he seems to catch his meaning, and jumps for the king, goo-gooing with all his might for joy, and hugs him about fifteen times before he lets up. Then the king says, “I knowed it; I reckon that’ll convince anybody the way he feels about it. Here, Mary Jane, Susan, Joanner, take the money—take it all. It’s the gift of him that lays yonder, cold but joyful.”
Mary Jane she went for him, Susan and the hare-lip went for the duke, and then such another hugging and kissing I never see yet. And everybody crowded up with the tears in their eyes, and most shook the hands off of them frauds, saying all the time:
“You dear good souls!—how lovely!—how could you!”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Say,” says the duke, “I got another idea. Le’s go up stairs and count this money, and then take and give it to the girls.”

“Good land!” says the king, relishing the notion. “That’s it! We’ll go up there and count it, and then I’ll make a speech, and I’ll say, ‘Here, my pure and lovely nieces, is your fortune. Take it and be happy. It’s the gift of your poor, dear, departed uncle, and I’m only his humble instrument.’ Yes, that’s the ticket!”

So up they went, the duke and the king, with me tagging along behind, feeling mighty uneasy. They went into the room where Peter Wilks lay, and the duke says, “Now, where did they say the money was hid?”

“In the cellar, behind the door, in a kind of a cubby-hole,” says the king.

“All right,” says the duke. “You stay here and keep watch, and I’ll fetch it.”

So the king sat down on a trunk, and the duke he lit a candle and went down into the cellar. Pretty soon he come back, puffing and blowing, with an old carpet-bag.

“Well, what did I tell you?” he says. “Here it is, just as they said.”

They dumped it out on the floor, and it was a pile of gold, sure enough. They begun to count it, and it was a slow job. The king, he’d count a pile and then forget how much it was, and have to start over. The duke, he was quicker, but he kept stopping to admire the shine of the gold.

Finally, after a long time, they got it all counted. The duke looked at the king, and the king looked at the duke.

“Well?” says the king.

“It’s all here,” says the duke. “Six thousand dollars, good as gold.”

“But it ain’t,” says the king, looking worried. “There’s a deficit. It’s short, duke. It’s upwards of four hundred dollars short.”

The duke looked thunderstruck. “No! You don’t tell me! Why, they said it was all here.”

“Well, it ain’t,” says the king. “And what are we going to do about it? We can’t give them short measure. It’ll look suspicious.”

The duke, he scratched his head. “That’s a fact. We got to make it up, somehow. How much have we got, out of the Nonesuch?”

They counted up their own money, the proceeds from their various scams, and it came to a little over four hundred dollars. “There,” says the duke. “We can just make it. It’ll clean us out, but we got to do it. We got to make a good impression.”

So they added their own money to the pile, and then they put it all back in the carpet-bag. Then they went downstairs, the king carrying the bag, and looking solemn and important.

events.title: The King's "Orgies" Blunder and Dr. Robinson's Scrutiny
detailed_summary: The conversation soon shifts back to the deceased Peter Wilks, with attendees reminiscing about his good qualities and the great loss his death represents.

While the King is speaking, a stern-looking, "iron-jawed" man (later identified as Dr. Robinson) enters from outside and stands listening and observing without saying anything, unnoticed by the engrossed audience.

The King, in the middle of his discourse, mentions that particular friends of the deceased are invited for the evening, but that tomorrow everyone is welcome because Peter respected and liked everybody, making it fitting for his "funeral orgies" to be public.
He continues speaking, clearly enjoying the sound of his own voice, and repeatedly brings up the term "funeral orgies."

The Duke, unable to tolerate the King's persistent misuse of the word, writes "obsequies, you old fool" on a scrap of paper, folds it, and, while making his usual "goo-goo" noises, passes it over people's heads to the King.

The King reads the note, puts it in his pocket, and remarks that although his brother William is afflicted, his heart is always right, adding that William was merely asking him to invite everyone to the funeral, which he was already doing.
He then calmly resumes his speech, once again dropping in the phrase "funeral orgies" periodically.
After using the term for the third time, he attempts to justify it, stating that "orgies" is the correct term, not the common "obsequies," which he claims is no longer used in England.

He provides a nonsensical etymology for "orgies," claiming it's derived from the Greek "orgo" (meaning outside, open, abroad) and the Hebrew "jeesum" (meaning to plant, cover up, hence inter), thus concluding that "funeral orgies" means an open or public funeral.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, then, pretty soon all hands got to talking about the diseased again, and how good he was, and what a loss he was, and all that; and before long a big iron-jawed man worked himself in there from outside, and stood a-listening and looking, and not saying anything; and nobody saying anything to him either, because the king was talking and they was all busy listening.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So, you see, funeral orgies is an open er public funeral.”

events.text_segment:
Well, then, pretty soon all hands got to talking about the diseased again, and how good he was, and what a loss he was, and all that; and before long a big iron-jawed man worked himself in there from outside, and stood a-listening and looking, and not saying anything; and nobody saying anything to him either, because the king was talking and they was all busy listening. The king was saying—in the middle of something he’d started in on—
“—they bein’ partickler friends o’ the diseased. That’s why they’re invited here this evenin’; but tomorrow we want all to come—everybody; for he respected everybody, he liked everybody, and so it’s fitten that his funeral orgies sh’d be public.”
And so he went a-mooning on and on, liking to hear himself talk, and every little while he fetched in his funeral orgies again, till the duke he couldn’t stand it no more; so he writes on a little scrap of paper, “obsequies, you old fool,” and folds it up, and goes to goo-gooing and reaching it over people’s heads to him. The king he reads it and puts it in his pocket, and says:
“Poor William, afflicted as he is, his heart’s aluz right. Asks me to invite everybody to come to the funeral—wants me to make ’em all welcome. But he needn’t a worried—it was jest what I was at.”
Then he weaves along again, perfectly ca’m, and goes to dropping in his funeral orgies again every now and then, just like he done before. And when he done it the third time he says:
“I say orgies, not because it’s the common term, because it ain’t—obsequies bein’ the common term—but because orgies is the right term. Obsequies ain’t used in England no more now—it’s gone out. We say orgies now in England. Orgies is better, because it means the thing you’re after more exact. It’s a word that’s made up out’n the Greek orgo, outside, open, abroad; and the Hebrew jeesum, to plant, cover up; hence inter. So, you see, funeral orgies is an open er public funeral.”

events.title: Dr. Robinson's Denunciation and Mary Jane's Unwavering Trust
detailed_summary: The narrator remarks that the King was the worst imposter he had ever encountered.
Just then, the iron-jawed man, Dr. Robinson, laughs openly in the King's face, shocking everyone present.
People exclaim, "Why, doctor!" and Abner Shackleford informs Dr. Robinson that the man is Harvey Wilks.
The King, smiling eagerly, extends his hand towards the doctor, asking if he is his poor brother's dear friend and physician.
Dr. Robinson sharply tells the King to keep his hands off, then critiques his speech, stating it's the worst imitation of an Englishman he has ever heard and flatly declares the King a fraud.

The crowd becomes agitated, surrounding Dr. Robinson, trying to placate him and explain that "Harvey" has demonstrated his identity in numerous ways, knowing everyone by name, even the dogs, and begging him not to hurt Harvey's or the poor girls' feelings.
However, Dr. Robinson remains unpersuaded, storming on and asserting that any man claiming to be English who couldn't imitate the accent better was undeniably a fraud and a liar.
The Wilks girls, crying, cling to the King.
Suddenly, Dr. Robinson turns his attention to the girls.

He declares himself their father's friend and, as their honest friend wanting to protect them, warns them to turn away from the "scoundrel" King, calling him an ignorant tramp with idiotic claims about Greek and Hebrew.
He asserts the King is a transparent impostor who has merely gathered some names and facts, which they and their foolish friends are mistaking for proof.
He appeals directly to Mary Jane Wilks, reminding her of his unselfish friendship, and begs her to expel the "pitiful rascal."
Mary Jane straightens up, looking striking in her resolve, and gives her answer by taking the bag of money and placing it into the King's hands.
She tells the King to take the $6,000 and invest it for her and her sisters as he sees fit, without needing to provide any receipt.
Then, she puts her arm around the King, and Susan and Joanna do the same on his other side, demonstrating their complete trust.
The crowd erupts in applause and stomping, while the King holds his head high and smiles proudly.
Dr. Robinson declares he is done with the matter but warns everyone present that a time will come when they will feel sick whenever they recall this day, and then he departs.
The King mockingly retorts, "All right, doctor, we’ll try and get ’em to send for you," a remark that causes the crowd to laugh, deeming it a clever hit.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “All right, doctor,” says the king, kinder mocking him; “we’ll try and get ’em to send for you;” which made them all laugh, and they said it was a prime good hit.

events.text_segment:
He was the worst I ever struck. Well, the iron-jawed man he laughed right in his face. Everybody was shocked. Everybody says, “Why, doctor!” and Abner Shackleford says:
“Why, Robinson, hain’t you heard the news? This is Harvey Wilks.”
The king he smiled eager, and shoved out his flapper, and says:
“Is it my poor brother’s dear good friend and physician? I—”
“Keep your hands off of me!” says the doctor. “You talk like an Englishman, don’t you? It’s the worst imitation I ever heard. You Peter Wilks’s brother! You’re a fraud, that’s what you are!”
Well, how they all took on! They crowded around the doctor and tried to quiet him down, and tried to explain to him and tell him how Harvey ’d showed in forty ways that he was Harvey, and knowed everybody by name, and the names of the very dogs, and begged and begged him not to hurt Harvey’s feelings and the poor girl’s feelings, and all that. But it warn’t no use; he stormed right along, and said any man that pretended to be an Englishman and couldn’t imitate the lingo no better than what he did was a fraud and a liar. The poor girls was hanging to the king and crying; and all of a sudden the doctor ups and turns on them. He says:
“I was your father’s friend, and I’m your friend; and I warn you as a friend, and an honest one that wants to protect you and keep you out of harm and trouble, to turn your backs on that scoundrel and have nothing to do with him, the ignorant tramp, with his idiotic Greek and Hebrew, as he calls it. He is the thinnest kind of an impostor—has come here with a lot of empty names and facts which he picked up somewheres, and you take them for proofs, and are helped to fool yourselves by these foolish friends here, who ought to know better. Mary Jane Wilks, you know me for your friend, and for your unselfish friend, too. Now listen to me; turn this pitiful rascal out—I beg you to do it. Will you?”
Mary Jane straightened herself up, and my, but she was handsome! She says:
“Here is my answer.” She hove up the bag of money and put it in the king’s hands, and says, “Take this six thousand dollars, and invest for me and my sisters any way you want to, and don’t give us no receipt for it.”
Then she put her arm around the king on one side, and Susan and the hare-lip done the same on the other. Everybody clapped their hands and stomped on the floor like a perfect storm, whilst the king held up his head and smiled proud. The doctor says:
“All right; I wash my hands of the matter. But I warn you all that a time ’s coming when you’re going to feel sick whenever you think of this day.” And away he went.
“All right, doctor,” says the king, kinder mocking him; “we’ll try and get ’em to send for you;” which made them all laugh, and they said it was a prime good hit.

events.title: Room Assignments and Initial Settling In
detailed_summary: After the townspeople depart, the King inquires with Mary Jane about available spare rooms.
Mary Jane generously offers her own larger room to 'Uncle Harvey' (the King) and a spare room to 'Uncle William' (the Duke).
She proposes to sleep on a cot in the room with her sisters, designating a small attic cubby with a pallet for Huck, whom the King refers to as his 'valley' (valet).
Mary Jane shows the King and Duke their rooms, which are described as plain but pleasant.

She offers to clear her personal belongings from her room if they are in 'Uncle Harvey's' way, but the King insists they add to the room's comfortable and homely atmosphere and should not be disturbed.
The Duke's room, though small, and Huck's cubby are deemed perfectly adequate.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Well, when they was all gone the king he asks Mary Jane how they was off for spare rooms, and she said she had one spare room, which would do for Uncle William, and she’d give her own room to Uncle Harvey, which was a little bigger, and she would turn into the room with her sisters and sleep on a cot; and up garret was a little cubby, with a pallet in it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The duke’s room was pretty small, but plenty good enough, and so was my cubby.

events.text_segment:
Well, when they was all gone the king he asks Mary Jane how they was off for spare rooms, and she said she had one spare room, which would do for Uncle William, and she’d give her own room to Uncle Harvey, which was a little bigger, and she would turn into the room with her sisters and sleep on a cot; and up garret was a little cubby, with a pallet in it. The king said the cubby would do for his valley—meaning me.
So Mary Jane took us up, and she showed them their rooms, which was plain but nice. She said she’d have her frocks and a lot of other traps took out of her room if they was in Uncle Harvey’s way, but he said they warn’t. The frocks was hung along the wall, and before them was a curtain made out of calico that hung down to the floor. There was an old hair trunk in one corner, and a guitar-box in another, and all sorts of little knickknacks and jimcracks around, like girls brisken up a room with. The king said it was all the more homely and more pleasanter for these fixings, and so don’t disturb them. The duke’s room was pretty small, but plenty good enough, and so was my cubby.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The king said the cubby would do for his valley—meaning me. So Mary Jane took us up, and she showed them the spare room, which was a very nice room, and the cubby either side of the chimney. Then she took me up to the garret, which was a little cubby, and had a pallet on the floor, and a glass window about as big as a pocket-handkerchief. She said she was sorry they hadn’t a better place for me, but she hoped I would be comfortable. I said I would. She was very kind and gentle. She was the best girl I ever see, and had the most sand. She warn’t particular; she was just sweet and simple and lovely to a degree that I can’t describe. I was mighty sorry to see her go.

events.title: Supper and Social Flattery
detailed_summary: Later that night, a large supper is held, attended by numerous local men and women.
Huck serves the King and Duke at their chairs, while other servants attend to the remaining guests.
Mary Jane, presiding at the head of the table with Susan beside her, politely disparages the quality of the food—claiming the biscuits, preserves, and fried chicken are subpar.
Huck recognizes this as a common social tactic employed by women to elicit compliments.

The guests, fully aware that the meal is excellent, respond with enthusiastic praise, inquiring about her cooking techniques for the biscuits and the origin of the pickles, engaging in the customary flattery typical of such social gatherings.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That night they had a big supper, and all them men and women was there, and I stood behind the king and the duke’s chairs and waited on them, and the niggers waited on the rest.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Mary Jane she set at the head of the table, with Susan alongside of her, and said how bad the biscuits was, and how mean the preserves was, and how ornery and tough the fried chickens was—and all that kind of rot, the way women always do for to force out compliments; and the people all knowed everything was tiptop, and said so—said “How do you get biscuits to brown so nice?” and “Where, for the land’s sake, did you get these amaz’n pickles?” and all that kind of humbug talky-talk, just the way people always does at a supper, you know.
